examples.1: [Lighthouse](https://developer.chrome.com/docs/lighthouse/overview?hl=en) is an open source project which enables both the auditing and production of reports of websites and applications for several common issues across a range of categories from within a web browser.

techniques.title: Provide active monitoring for issues on a frequent schedule
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.19 Audit and test for bugs or issues requiring resolution](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#audit-and-test-for-bugs-or-issues-requiring-resolution).

description.1: Ensure that problems relating to the sustainability of a website can be picked up with more frequency and regularity. Within the scope of website and application testing, it is important to be actively monitoring for common failure points that build over time and upon being notified of said issues provide resolutions within a reasonable timeframe.
description.2: Machine testability for this implementation will be based on the mechanism used for testing. For instance, if a product or service provider chooses to simply run routine tests on a scheduled basis this may be considered a pass as long as the time between scans is frequent enough that it can be considered active in opposition to occasional (weekly would be the widest margin).

procedure.1: Check that testing occurs hourly/daily/weekly to be considered active.
procedure.2: Check that all publicly visible pages are included within the monitoring.
procedure.3: Check that the facility providing the monitoring meets the WSG.
procedure.4: Check that a report of ongoing listed issues is publicly available until fully resolved.
procedure.5: Provide resolutions for detected issues within a timely manner.

examples.1: [Speedcurve](https://www.speedcurve.com/) is a commercial product that actively monitors websites for performance issues (broken down by category in rendering) and can provide advisory guidance on meeting targets for performance budgets.
examples.2: [Google Search Console](https://search.google.com/search-console/about) is a free product that monitors websites for issues that may affect their ability to be indexed within the Google search engine, which notably can impact their overall global page visibility.

techniques.title: Scan for introduced issues upon the completion of a new release
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.19 Audit and test for bugs or issues requiring resolution](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#audit-and-test-for-bugs-or-issues-requiring-resolution).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for eliminating any potential new flaws that may have been introduced into a website or application upon the release of a new version that will have additional updates or features that could break functionality if not implemented correctly. As such, enforcing a sustainability scan across a series of factors is critical.
description.2: For machine testability, the necessity of automation of running a scan could be triggered on the publication of each new release, or for more nuanced control (where active monitoring already exists and non-breaking features are being introduced), a scan could be triggered only where only a major release is issued when breaking changes are more likely to occur.

procedure.1: Check that all publicly visible pages are included within the monitoring.
procedure.2: Check for a wide variety of issues within the scope of the WSG.
procedure.3: Check that a report of ongoing listed issues is publicly available until fully resolved.
procedure.4: Provide resolutions for detected issues within a timely manner.

examples.1: [Accessibility scanners](https://www.w3.org/WAI/test-evaluate/tools/list/) can use the machine-testable elements of WCAG to help identify issues that can be resolved. While they are not a silver bullet and cannot replace manual audits they can identify some issues.

techniques.title: Establish performance testing routines with each new release
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.19 Audit and test for bugs or issues requiring resolution](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#audit-and-test-for-bugs-or-issues-requiring-resolution).

description.1: Encourage a routine to improve web performance within websites and applications due to the established link between web performance optimization and digital sustainability. Running regular benchmarks and working from checklists (either prefabricated or built from scratch) will encourage a schedule to identify potential bottlenecks.
description.2: The content of these testing routines can potentially be further tested through automation however at a bare minimum, this list must be utilized in-house to enact sustainable change. For machine testability, if this list is not publicly visible, internal access will be required to determine whether creation has taken place.

procedure.1: Check to see if deliverables require internal access (if so, permission is given).
procedure.2: Check that the testing regime is available (internally or externally).
procedure.3: Identify all web performance tests to perform during the testing process.
procedure.4: Report and resolve the findings within your auditing process.

examples.1: Smashing Magazine has a comprehensive [front-end performance checklist](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/01/front-end-performance-2021-free-pdf-checklist/) that could be utilized as part of a routine in release schedule checking for web performance issues that may exist or have been introduced.
examples.2: [Addy Osmani back in 2018](https://dev.to/ben/addy-osmanis-18-point-web-performance-checklist-2e1) created an 18-point web performance checklist that if you are looking for something more simplistic and rapid to compare builds against could potentially be very useful as a starting point.

techniques.title: Provide compliance checks with each release for relevant legislation
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.19 Audit and test for bugs or issues requiring resolution](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#audit-and-test-for-bugs-or-issues-requiring-resolution).

description.1: Provide a mechanism during the development process where businesses and individuals creating web projects can verify that new work meets compliance targets for individual regulations. This technique is most useful when performed with each major milestone as there is a potential for feature (and compliance) breaking material to occur.
description.2: Within the scope of sustainability, this is increasingly important as there are explicit laws surrounding the subject in addition to expanded PPP remits such as accessibility, privacy, etc. In terms of machine testability the mechanics of an implementation may be more difficult than utilizing an automated checker, but wizard software can work through questions to help identify key issues.

procedure.1: Check to see if deliverables require internal access (if so, permission is given).
procedure.2: Check that the testing regime is available (internally or externally).
procedure.3: Identify all relevant compliance checks to perform during testing process.
procedure.4: Report and resolve the findings within your auditing process.

examples.1: Internationally reaching environmental legislation such as [CSRD](https://finance.ec.europa.eu/capital-markets-union-and-financial-markets/company-reporting-and-auditing/company-reporting/corporate-sustainability-reporting_en) and the [Green Claims Directive](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/news/en/press-room/20240112IPR16772/meps-adopt-new-law-banning-greenwashing-and-misleading-product-information) provide stricter enforcement around product descriptions and the need to reduce emissions and accurately report such efforts.
examples.2: Accessibility legislation ([of which there are many worldwide](https://www.w3.org/WAI/policies/)) provides strict enforcement around ensuring inclusivity not just offline but also in the digital sphere as well, leaving non-compliance open to lawsuit risks.
examples.3: Internationally reaching privacy legislation such as [GDPR](https://gdpr-info.eu/) can also impact digital services on a sustainability level (through the people and societal aspect of PPP), and [various](https://gdpr.eu/checklist/) [checklists](https://gdprchecklist.io/) can assist.

techniques.title: Provide a publicly visible compatibility policy or statement
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.21 Regularly test and maintain compatibility](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#regularly-test-and-maintain-compatibility).

description.1: Ensure that users are made aware of (or able to find out) the limitations of a product or service before issuing a support request that will involve creating new emission sources. This compatibility policy can be listed amongst other policies on a website, however, it must contain detailed information about any factor that may have reduced capability.
description.2: For machine testability, attempt to first establish that the policy exists and then try using heuristics (or identification of the headlines) to locate sections on what is both actively supported (those conditions tested upon), and those that are confirmed as unsupported (those conditions known to be broken but will not be fixed with reasons given). Ensure that a support method is also provided.

procedure.1: Check for a compatibility policy or statement's existence.
procedure.2: Check for sections on included and excluded coverage.
procedure.3: Check that a support method is offered for issues outside of scope.

examples.1: British cellphone provider GiffGaff provides a [web browser support policy](https://www.giffgaff.design/guidelines/browser-support-policy/) that identifies which browsers they support and do not actively support.

techniques.title: Provide clarification when updates are significant over minor releases
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.21 Regularly test and maintain compatibility](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#regularly-test-and-maintain-compatibility).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for introducing users to new features and capabilities within websites and applications upon a major release being triggered. This would include compatibility changes, any alterations that affect workflow, and bugs that have been resolved. It applies equally to both applications on upgrade paths and website redesigns.
description.2: The importance of re-orientating users around breaking changes is crucial as modifications made could lead to errors in usage, increases in technical support, problematic friction in usability or accessibility, or introduction of issues that may lead to multiple impacting PPP factors that could be resolved through training, answered questions, and well-signposted information architecture.

procedure.1: Check for a publicly available change.log or release notes.
procedure.2: Check that the frequency of updates has not been less than 12 months.
procedure.3: Check that major releases provide details of breaking features.

examples.1: Using [Semantic Versioning](https://semver.org/), providers through their release notes (which if publicly available could be machine tested against), could easily identify a major (breakable significant), against a minor (non-breaking) release.

techniques.title: Establish compatibility testing routines with each new release
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.21 Regularly test and maintain compatibility](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#regularly-test-and-maintain-compatibility).

description.1: Ensure that compatibility issues resulting from user constraints (such as operating system or browser age/connection speed, availability, or cost) are factored into the testing process at each new release. Creators must have processes in place whether through checklists that are pre-created or crafted from scratch to ensure that a regime is in place. Other contingencies exist (such as geo-blocking or mobile data costs) and these can also be taken into account if detection is possible.
description.2: In terms of machine testability, some tools can provide virtualized emulations of certain operating systems and thereby load products and services to undertake tests (or screenshots) to examine compatibility. Data also exists regarding mobile data charges and connection speeds which can be used to emulate or identify the compatibility costs associated with projects.
description.3: If detection is not available (such as in cases where the Internet is unavailable), Non-digital investigation should be conducted where possible (such as through the use of mail or telephone feedback). Once the constraint has been detected, it will often be up to the developer to create a solution that will involve compatibility features or reducing the load on the user's device to increase ease of access. If there are questions regarding the potential compatibility or availability of services due to a certain configuration, seek the manufacturer's advice for further guidance.

procedure.1: Check to see if deliverables require internal access (if so, permission is given).
procedure.2: Check that the testing regime is available (internally or externally).
procedure.3: Identify all compatibility tests to perform during the testing process.
procedure.4: Check if additional legal compliance requirements are being met.
procedure.5: Report and resolve the findings within your auditing process.

examples.1: [Browser Stack](https://www.browserstack.com/) and [LambadaTest](https://www.lambdatest.com/) provide virtual testing (which can be automated) amongst a variety of common web browsers allowing testers to identify flaws in their website or application's compatibility.
examples.2: [Can I Use](https://caniuse.com/) and [Can I WebView](https://caniwebview.com/) provide a comprehensive guide to browser implementations of web standards, including known bugs, and thereby can help guide implementors with decision making when deciding how to progressively enhance their product or service.
examples.3: Certain political situations may result in the inability for users to access your product or service hassle-free such as geo-blocking restrictions, the cost of bandwidth, or government-enacted firewalls, filters, or authentication requirements.

techniques.title: Provide a PWA if more suitable than its native counterpart
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.21 Regularly test and maintain compatibility](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#regularly-test-and-maintain-compatibility).

description.1: Identify a web application that exists and then determine if turning the web application into a progressive web application would be more beneficial than providing a native offering. This would need to take into account current web capabilities (such as ServiceWorkers), methods of delivery (such as WASM), and the human aspect (audience requirements).
description.2: Machine testability can firstly examine the existing state of an application to determine how sustainable it is and what technology stack was used to develop it (and how sustainable it already performs for all), from there, data points can be used to identify an approximate cost of implementation for both a native or highly optimized web application endpoint and options can be provided.

procedure.1: Check if the existing application already utilizes a ServiceWorker.
procedure.2: If so, check the PWA JavaScript and JSON are well formed, and the icon exists.
procedure.3: If not calculate the sustainability impact of becoming a PWA.
procedure.4: Check that no native application already exists ([meta tag smart banner](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/webkit/promoting-apps-with-smart-app-banners)).
procedure.5: If so use that, otherwise calculate the sustainability impact of building an application.
procedure.6: If cost-efficient sustainability-wise, implement a PWA or/and a native application.

examples.1: Native applications may be a good choice if applications require specific access to hardware as web APIs can still be quite restrictive. In addition, there is a case for going native to provide a more OS-centric look and feel.
examples.2: web applications are often quicker and easier to deploy and can provide updates without delays in the pipeline (as they do not have to go through store controls), they can also benefit from lower creation costs.

techniques.title: Profile existing projects to identify common factors of value
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.1 Set goals based on performance and energy impact](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#set-goals-based-on-performance-and-energy-impact).

description.1: Identify any technical indicators which may be of use within a sustainability budget or those that can be immediately identified as exceeding a recommended level for an average page size thereby indicating that the document should be split or broken down into either two or more pieces to reduce the impact of the experience upon the user.
description.2: Factors that may be taken into account could include an extremely long document that would require excessive scrolling (based on either the visual spacing or the number of DOM elements involved), the number of DOM elements could also be a factor as too many could produce unwarranted rendering loads, also excessive HTTP requests can produce a lot of overhead.

procedure.1: Check the visual spacing of elements is not too cramped.
procedure.2: Check the scroll length of the document does not exceed a stated length.
procedure.3: Check the number of DOM nodes in the tree does not exceed a stated number.
procedure.4: Check the number of HTTP requests does not exceed a stated number.
procedure.5: Check if optimizing will be beneficial, if so, implement a solution.

examples.1: Websites that need to display a large number of icons may choose to bundle the [vector images into a sprite](https://levelup.gitconnected.com/build-an-icon-system-with-svg-sprites-a-complete-guide-1e195820ac6a) which avoids the HTTP requests overhead and allows requesting (and repeat usage) through references.

techniques.title: Calculate the energy intensity of technologies for existing projects
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.1 Set goals based on performance and energy impact](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#set-goals-based-on-performance-and-energy-impact).

description.1: Distinguish different technologies and the role they play, identifying which are the most resource-intensive and providing either a mechanism to reduce the intensity of heavy payloads or to load-balance the most demanding aspects of these features. It is important to consider that in terms of rendering, data transfer is not the only consideration.
description.2: In terms of machine testability, calculating the percentage of HTML, CSS, JavaScript, images, media, etc, is not enough. It is critical to weigh and calculate the energy requirements of each aspect of those languages on an atomic level to identify potential rendering issues from the browser as these will impact upon hardware (CPU, GPU, RAM, and other factors) having PPP implications.

procedure.1: Check the energy intensity of the HTML elements and attributes used.
procedure.2: Check the energy intensity of CSS at-rules, selectors, pseudo's, properties, and Values.
procedure.3: Check the energy intensity of JavaScript, DOM, CSSOM, and API usage.
procedure.4: Check the energy intensity of image and media usage.

examples.1: Primary [research exists](https://websitesustainability.com/#content) to calculate the energy intensity of front-end specifications and this could guide your ability to identify the energy intensity of components beyond the amount of data transferred.
examples.2: [Co2.js](https://www.thegreenwebfoundation.org/co2-js/) is a JavaScript library that can help developers estimate the relative carbon emissions of their applications, websites, and software using several factors (though it will not account for everything).

techniques.title: Minify your front-end code if it is public facing
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.2 Remove unnecessary or redundant information](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#remove-unnecessary-or-redundant-information).

description.1: Provide a mechanism in which your production-ready source code can have unnecessary data such as code comments, white space data, and machine-detectable redundancy removed to deliver the smallest file payload possible to the user. This will improve both the speed of your site and lower screen usage (wait) time.
description.2: In terms of machine testability, the functions of a minification tool can be replicated for the languages HTML, CSS, and JavaScript using scripts and these can identify improvements to be made. Function names can be uglified (shortened to the smallest value) to reduce the size of the payload further and reporting tools can make recommendations based upon feedback.

procedure.1: Check if your HTML, CSS, and JavaScript can be minified.
procedure.2: Check if JavaScript can gain size reductions through uglify processes.
procedure.3: Check if the code is on a non-production public-facing website.
procedure.4: Check if obfuscation exists, if not minify the source code.

examples.1: Projects that are both public-facing but also allow for others to contribute to development should allow for [un-minification](https://unminify.com/). Developer tooling often contains features or extensions to restore code to a readable state.
examples.2: [Mithril](https://mithril.js.org/) is an example of a JavaScript framework that uses minification to great effect. It is small to start with but by offering both developer and minified versions on its GitHub repository you get the best of both worlds.

techniques.title: Implement code-splitting where appropriate to reduce payloads
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.3 Modularize bandwidth-heavy components](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#modularize-bandwidth-heavy-components).

description.1: Provide a mechanism where modularization can occur to reduce the overall payload of applications, libraries, and frameworks for the web. By using code-splitting and modules where isolating code can take place (machine-testability can detect this), large components can be successfully broken down into pieces that will be delivered as required.
description.2: This technique is most useful when dealing with significant-sized or complex pieces of production code that may not be required to be delivered in a single volume. If functionality will be used on-demand (for example), the payload to activate and run the functionality could be fetched and run when it is needed instead of the entire applications library being gathered upon page load.

procedure.1: Check the size of packages to determine the benefit of code-splitting.
procedure.2: Check if CSS would benefit from being split into separate style sheets based on queries.
procedure.3: Check if JavaScript can be modularized and imported when required.
procedure.4: Check if obfuscation exists, if not code-split the source code.

examples.1: MDN [provides a detailed guide](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Guide/Modules) to JavaScript modules that are contained within many frameworks today to split them into separate component-based libraries to be called only when they are required by the user.
examples.2: Separating CSS into style sheets based on arguments such as [media or preference queries](https://polypane.app/blog/the-complete-guide-to-css-media-queries/) (or in rarer instances using imports), allows for large stylistic libraries to be broken down and requested only if its necessary.
examples.3: [Alpine](https://alpinejs.dev/) is a JavaScript framework that uses modules effectively to import the features it requires, and as such, remains fast and lightweight compared to competing frameworks that load everything in one go.

techniques.title: Eliminate redundant code through coverage or tree shaking
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.4 Remove unnecessary code](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#remove-unnecessary-code).

description.1: Eliminate redundancy within an application or website that may have been either introduced previously or through error. By using browser development tooling such as DevTools coverage or techniques like tree shaking any code which is no longer associated with functionality can be identified as potentially fit for removal (always verify this is accurate).
description.2: For machine testability, redundant (orphaned/unused) code can be identified by its lack of association with existing components within the web page or application. Consideration will also need to be given to components that may be generated mid or post-render in addition to styles that only trigger when a certain state occurs (such as through hover or the target pseudo selector).

procedure.1: Check CSS to determine if redundancy exists within your code.
procedure.2: Check packages to determine if redundancy exists within JavaScript.
procedure.3: Check if redundant code may be reintroduced, if not, remove it.

examples.1: [This article by Jeremy Wagner](https://web.dev/articles/reduce-javascript-payloads-with-tree-shaking?hl=en) showcases the importance of tree shaking within projects, including the history behind it and how it functions, in addition, it provides a few useful code examples.
examples.2: You can identify unused code within a project using Google Developer Tools in the [Coverage Panel](https://developer.chrome.com/docs/devtools/coverage?hl=en-us). While there are a few gotchas (such as identifying inactive pseudo selectors), it is a useful way to weed CSS.

techniques.title: Write code for performance removing duplication
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.5 Avoid redundancy and duplication in code](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#avoid-redundancy-and-duplication-in-code).

description.1: Provide a mechanism within projects to eliminate redundancy within your coding methodology. There will be occasions where the same solution is required for multiple events and in preference to repeating the code to achieve the same effect, referencing the code to perform on each occasion is more optimal as it reduces duplication and repetition.
description.2: In terms of machine testability, usage of DRY, repeated CSS property and value pairs (or in JavaScript, code that repeats the same action) can be identified and flagged as appropriate in cases where the implementation is correct or incorrect based upon the pattern. Where patterns add unnecessary bloat to a page (such as CSS methodologies), detection can be identified and flagged in such instances.

procedure.1: Check for energy inefficient naming methodologies or patterns in CSS.
procedure.2: Check for the absence of repeating code (DRY) within CSS.
procedure.3: Check for duplicate functionality or names within your JavaScript.

examples.1: [DRY](https://csswizardry.com/2013/07/writing-dryer-vanilla-css/ is a methodology that is commonly used by creating reusable components and patterns, using easier-to-name schemes and most importantly, avoiding already established code.

techniques.title: Determine and decision make upon third-party impacts
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.6 Give third parties the same priority as first parties during assessment](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#give-third-parties-the-same-priority-as-first-parties-during-assessment).

description.1: First identify any third-party components within a website or application, then analyze that feature as if it were a first-party product or service (against the WSG) for sustainability. If the product or service is determined to be highly impactful in a negative way, the third-party should be replaced or removed; otherwise, it can be optimized, or stay as-is.
description.2: As third-party components are hosted externally, machine testing these elements should involve isolating these components and testing them as separate from the product or service. This can be factored into any decision-making regarding inclusion as highly performant and sustainable third-party materials will ultimately be low impact (and the opposite is true for others).

procedure.1: Check if any third-party components exist within the page or application.
procedure.2: Check that component against the WSG for its sustainability compliance.
procedure.3: Check if high-impact third-party components offer self-hosted alternatives.
procedure.4: Check that self-hosted alternatives are used if provided.

examples.1: [OpenStreetMap](https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Using_OpenStreetMap) allows for [embedding of their map data](https://medium.com/@nargessmi87/how-to-embede-open-street-map-in-a-webpage-like-google-maps-8968fdad7fe4) in websites and applications which can be useful for providing directions to physical locations, but it could also drain data and rendering resources.
examples.2: A carousel with multiple resources (potentially being sourced from a third-party photo library) could be pretty to look at, but the combination of both animation and rendering may affect your user's battery.

techniques.title: Provide an import on interaction delay for third-party resources
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.6 Give third parties the same priority as first parties during assessment](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#give-third-parties-the-same-priority-as-first-parties-during-assessment).

description.1: Provide a mechanism to delay third-party content from loading to the screen until the user has requested it. Because third-party content is sourced from outside the origin domain, the sustainability impacts of the third-party code are outside of the control of a project, and thus click-to-load delay screens using the import-on-interaction pattern is critical.
description.2: The pattern used to either switch in the third-party content or load it on-demand can be machine-identified and if common third-party library resources are identified as loading (or leaking) upon a visit, this can and should be flagged up as a failure of the success criteria in functioning upon the user request (as such external requests should be within the user control).

procedure.1: Check if any third-party components exist within the page or application.
procedure.2: Check that it exists behind a click-to-load delay screen (that users must request).

examples.1: [BBC News](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-68590845) uses a cloaking mechanism to prevent third-party content of social media sites from loading unless requested by the user to reduce the impact on their devices (if this fails to work, a source link is offered).
examples.2: Google provides details on how to [Lazy load offscreen iframes](https://web.dev/articles/iframe-lazy-loading) in order to reduce the impact that third-party materials that are imported may have until they are scrolled into the viewport and required.

techniques.title: Ensure that content is delivered through the most sustainable pathway
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.6 Give third parties the same priority as first parties during assessment](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#give-third-parties-the-same-priority-as-first-parties-during-assessment).

description.1: Identify the location of website content and determine the most suitable pathway for it to be consumed sustainably. With the rise in content being hosted on third-party blogging platforms, there is a risk of significant content loss if the platform disappears and therefore a need for self-hosting exists (especially to maintain control of sustainability impacts).
description.2: For machine testability, identifying the source of the content is a key priority, then determining the impact of any third-party (the risk of content loss along with any sustainability impacts through WSG testing). Finally, this should be weighed up against the impact of self-hosting (and any potential negative consequences such as content moderation requirements that may occur).

procedure.1: Check if the level of content being published is regular.
procedure.2: Check if features such as comments are a requirement (if so, can moderation be offered).
procedure.3: Check if the website already has an audience to give content visibility.
procedure.4: If so, check that the content is self-hosted on the first-party domain.

examples.1: [Medium](https://medium.com/) is a popular content hosting platform yet while it does offer a reasonably readable interface, it may not be as sustainable as providing the content within your own website or application in a dedicated blog.
examples.2: Social media posts are contained within your account on that network (in some social networks are only visible to members or even users of a mobile application) and will have the sustainability issues of that provider.

techniques.title: Provide the ability to identify and choose third-party components to load
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.6 Give third parties the same priority as first parties during assessment](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#give-third-parties-the-same-priority-as-first-parties-during-assessment).

description.1: Provide users with the optimum level of control over sustainability impacts by not just allowing them to identify and load third-party controls upon click but to also control third-party services, libraries, and tooling used by the product or service (even at load) via a preference panel where individual third-parties (which may be impactful) can be refused access.
description.2: This mechanism if using a commonly accepted scheme could be detected by a machine. If the preference is presented upon load and not set by default and if the user has the option of selecting individual services (one at a time), accepting all, and denying all, then it can be deemed that the functionality is working as expected (as long as third-party services obey that scheme).

procedure.1: Check that information is provided to indicate upon load to indicate preferences.
procedure.2: Check that the option to allow all, deny all, and select between providers is offered.
procedure.3: Check that information is provided identifying providers and describing the options carefully.
procedure.4: Check that preferences are remembered when navigating during the session.

examples.1: Cookie banners are a classic example of personalization from the point of the page load and they can dictate the functionality of a website or application based on the choices made [as shown in this example](https://www.optimizely.com/).
examples.2: Being able to log into to a product allows customers to trigger decisions regarding their experience. [Apple Music](https://music.apple.com/us/new) (for example) uses the details of the user to make decisions based on their prior browsing habits.

techniques.title: Validate source code for semantic accuracy
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.7 Ensure code follows good semantic practices](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#ensure-code-follows-good-semantic-practices).

description.1: Ensure that HTML uses accurate semantics (Semantic HTML). Use the correct semantic element for the correct purpose and avoid common syntax mistakes that could be easily correctable. In terms of web sustainability it is important to have code that remains as likely to stay functional in the future as possible.
description.2: For machine testability, examining code for correct element use is a primary step. Other features found in validation services such as ensuring elements are closed correctly and that HTML entities are correctly marked up help avoid rare issues that might occur during the rendering process such as web browsers accidentally interpreting data incorrectly.

procedure.1: Check if the HTML, CSS, and other source code contains resolvable errors.
procedure.2: Check that any errors have been successfully linted and corrected.

examples.1: W3C provides markup validation services for [HTML](https://validator.w3.org/) and [CSS](https://jigsaw.w3.org/css-validator/), [JSON](https://jsonlint.com/), as well as [feeds](https://validator.w3.org/feed/) to identify potential issues with the code. These tools can work with direct input as well as files and direct input.
examples.2: Linting tools can check (and be configured) to help you find and resolve common errors either while you code or during an auditing process. There are linting tools available for languages like [HTML](https://markuplint.dev/), [CSS](https://stylelint.io/), [JavaScript](https://eslint.org/).

techniques.title: Eliminate optional code to reduce the rendering impact
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.7 Ensure code follows good semantic practices](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#ensure-code-follows-good-semantic-practices).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for eliminating further redundancy from source code which may not be strictly required for semantic reasons but can help reduce the amount of data being transferred and thereby improve web performance. This can be done by removing any optional code from a document that will not affect the rendering of the page.
description.2: This technique is most useful when subscribing to performance budgets and attempting to reach the smallest file size possible is of critical importance to reach PPP targets. Such optional code removal can be identified by machine and recommendations for where optimization can occur can be provided but there may be occasions (as with minification) in non-production to retain the data.

procedure.1: Check that optional HTML elements that are unnecessary for rendering are removed.
procedure.2: Check that browser default styles are not repeated in the style sheets.

examples.1: [This article by Jens Oliver Meiert](https://meiert.com/en/blog/optional-html/) provides details about some of the optional HTML elements you may wish to eliminate to reduce the amount of data being transferred to users during a page view session.
examples.2: [Browser Default Styles](https://browserdefaultstyles.com/) provides information about the CSS that a web browser will render to the user as a matter of course when an HTML element is created (therefore you do not need to repeat the statements).

techniques.title: Replace non-standard code with suitable alternative syntax
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.7 Ensure code follows good semantic practices](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#ensure-code-follows-good-semantic-practices).

description.1: Identify and eliminate any non-standard or deprecated coding practices including but not limited to proprietary additions included by web browsers to test new functionality before potentially including it fully within the web browser (this is not so common today but remnants still exist). As older code is often not as highly optimized for performance, it can take longer to render and thrash hardware causing higher emissions so is worth resolving.
description.2: For machine testability, lists of non-standard or deprecated syntax are available within common specifications which can be used to identify within source code. In addition, browser-specific code can be identified by its prefix or on lists of techniques and hacks to resolve browser bugs. If replacements for these techniques can be offered, provide them, otherwise recommend removal from your code.
description.3: The [Space Jam website](https://www.spacejam.com/1996/) is considered a classic piece of 90s Internet design with its total disregard for function over form, but if you look at the code - it gets even uglier with table-based layouts and deprecated code
description.4: The [Web Design Museum](https://www.webdesignmuseum.org/flash-websites) houses a showcase of screenshots of websites that were built using the proprietary technology Adobe Flash. Along with Java Applets and Microsoft Silverlight they now no longer work.

procedure.1: Check that archaic proprietary specification additions are not included within the code.
procedure.2: Check that browser prefixes have been removed from CSS unless required for compatibility.
procedure.3: Check that no browser hacks exist unless they are required for compatibility.

examples.1: In the past, it was necessary to provide specific coding techniques (known as hacks) to ensure web browser compatibility. [Browser Hacks](http://browserhacks.com/), lists the various patterns used that could be solutions fit for removal.
examples.2: When [testing new features](https://ios404.com/), browsers had a habit of [prefixing their code](https://shouldiprefix.com/) in the past [behind flags](https://webstatus.dev/) to avoid breaking existing code. Lists of such prefixes can be found online as well as archaic proprietary HTML and CSS. Websites like [BCD Watch](https://bcd-watch.igalia.com/), [CSS Triggers](https://css-triggers.com/), [Runtime compatibility?](https://runtime-compat.unjs.io/), and [Web features explorer](https://web-platform-dx.github.io/web-features-explorer/) can help with compatibility testing.
examples.3: Check that the project does not contain any outdated layout techniques (such as table-based design).
examples.4: Check that the website or application does not contain deprecated syntax features.
examples.5: Check if the existing product or service uses outdated technologies (VML/P3P, etc) and if so recommend replacements (X3D/POWDER, etc).
examples.6: Check for proprietary web plugins (like Flash) and remove them until a replacement can be created.

techniques.title: Replace code that can instead use more efficient native APIs
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.7 Ensure code follows good semantic practices](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#ensure-code-follows-good-semantic-practices).

description.1: First identify and then determine if custom JavaScript functions could be replaced with a more optimal and established native API call. This will also apply to custom element creation over using established native features to the browser. With the evolution of JavaScript, the opportunity to optimize code with newer cleaner techniques occurs regularly.
description.2: It is preferable to measure both the newer method of implementation with the older method to identify if one provides a more optimized (via performance and sustainability metrics) implementation than the other before replacement. Also, this technique is most useful when considering if the custom component provides additional functionality that the native component does not and if such features weigh up beneficially against the cleaner native implementation.

procedure.1: Check if the benefits of a native browser control exceed creating a custom element.
procedure.2: Check if a native API exists that could replace custom calls, methods, or functions.
procedure.3: In either of these instances, if the answer is yes, check that the native option is used.

examples.1: MDN provides a [great list of native web APIs](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API) for JavaScript including the interfaces that can be used to call them. Within each of those items, you will find detailed documentation along with examples of usage.

techniques.title: Set scripts to load either asynchronously or deferred
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.8 Defer the loading of non-critical resources](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#defer-the-loading-of-non-critical-resources).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for JavaScript (and if possible style sheets) to be loaded asynchronously or deferred to avoid acting as render blocking events which can delay the loading of content. This will lessen the initial impact on users' hardware and thus can have PPP and web performance benefits which should be taken into account.
description.2: This technique is most useful when it is applied to all materials which will run upon the page load. In terms of testing for this technique, scripts can be identified by the attribute being provided within the HTML code. If the attribute is not provided, guidance can be offered to question if this was intentional or machine testing could analyze the code to verify if an issue will occur.

procedure.1: Check that all scripts are set to load with either the async or defer attributes unless necessary.
procedure.2: Check if CSS ([with the aid of JavaScript](https://www.holisticseo.digital/pagespeed/async-css/)) could benefit from asynchronous loading, and if so, do it.

examples.1: [Chart.js](https://www.chartjs.org/docs/latest/samples/tooltip/content.html) is a library that allows you to easily produce complex charts within a website or application. It uses a combination of asynchronous and deferred loading to ensure the rendering does not block other content.

techniques.title: Provide assets required at load with the correct delivery route
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.8 Defer the loading of non-critical resources](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#defer-the-loading-of-non-critical-resources).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for assets to be loaded at the correct time in the rendering process. With the ability to use preload, prefetch, and preconnect we can take resources such as web fonts and scripts that are necessary for the product or service to successfully be able to be displayed and ensure they are prioritized over other web assets.
description.2: Identifying that the asset being chosen for this mechanism is correct, linked to correctly, and has the right mechanism in place is of the highest priority for machine testers to ensure that the rendering process is not interrupted. If a low-priority object is given high priority it could delay the website or application from reaching the user and increase screen time.

procedure.1: Check that preload, prefetch, and preconnect are used as appropriate in HTML documents.

examples.1: [Mightybytes](https://www.mightybytes.com/) uses DNS prefetching to ensure that fonts and JavaScript that are hosted on a third-party CDN service will be less likely to suffer render-blocking (as the host is readied before the content is requested).
examples.2: [Wholegrain Digital](https://www.wholegraindigital.com/) uses preloading on its web typography to avoid render blocking with several different weights being offered on the same typeface (all of which will be downloaded as the content is).

techniques.title: Add signposting within the page to direct users and accessibility aids
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.9 Provide information to help understand the usefulness of a page](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#provide-information-to-help-understand-the-usefulness-of-a-page).

description.1: Provide mechanisms to assist the user with finding and navigating through content within the page or application. This can come in the form of links that allow you to bypass blocks of content, which is especially useful when large vocal areas of navigation or other content exist. It could also be in the form of keyboard shortcuts that activate certain features within a complex application rather than having to click multiple steps.
description.2: Machine testability for such features can identify events within JavaScript or features that use common patterns in code that are recognized as helpful signposting features. If such features are present then the success criteria can be marked as compliant but if none are found it could be an indicator, especially in complex websites or applications that such features are needed.

procedure.1: Check that the project can be successfully navigated using the keyboard.
procedure.2: Check that the tabindex order of the content makes logical, navigable sense.
procedure.3: Check that skip links exist to guide accessibility tools through content.
procedure.4: Check that keyboard shortcuts are well documented and work as expected.
procedure.5: Check that signposting within pages are well described, and work as directed.

examples.1: [WebAim has a great article](https://webaim.org/techniques/skipnav/) describing the details relating to skip links [as does Jim Thatcher](https://www.jimthatcher.com/skipnav.htm), both include plenty of useful visual examples and situations to work with when designing a custom solution of your own.
examples.2: Smashing Magazine published a [two](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2022/11/guide-keyboard-accessibility-html-css-part1/) [part](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2022/11/guide-keyboard-accessibility-javascript-part2/) guide to keyboard accessibility which included HTML, CSS, and JavaScript and covered not only skip links but also provided keyboard-based accessibility aids.

techniques.title: Ensure that form inputs correctly match and validate content expectations
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.10 Validate form errors and account for tooling requirements](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#validate-form-errors-and-account-for-tooling-requirements).

description.1: Ensure that input types correctly match the type of content being placed within them, that content types like passwords are handled in a way that users can easily reveal them, and that the patterns attribute is used correctly to help reduce errors during data entry. In doing so, problematic friction encountered during form filling can be reduced as can erroneous submissions.
description.2: Machine testability for this criteria will involve analyzing the components of forms to ensure they are well formed and that (for example) any regular expressions used in patterns will not produce an erroneous result. It is also important that functionality within forms perform well on mobile devices as well as desktop so consideration must be given to the choice of input for tasks.

procedure.1: Check that the input type matches the expected content type.
procedure.2: Check that the use of the pattern attribute does not prevent correct input.
procedure.3: Check that regular expressions are correctly formed and do not equate errors.
procedure.4: Check that password fields can be made visible to allow for recognition.
procedure.5: Check that one input type will function well on mobile devices over another.

examples.1: [This article from TheGood](https://thegood.com/insights/form-design-examples/) showcases multiple examples of great form design not only from the point of the user experience but also in the development to ensure that the ability to make mistakes is reduced.

techniques.title: Ensure that form elements are correctly labeled
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.10 Validate form errors and account for tooling requirements](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#validate-form-errors-and-account-for-tooling-requirements).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for accessibility tooling to be able to accurately describe the content of form features and to provide visual aids for users aiming to identify what information is required to be entered. This technique requires all interactive elements within the form to have an associated label to describe the purpose and/or role of the item.
description.2: Labels should be presented directly beside the element in question to imply association and if multiple associations are required, a grouping element with a label can be provided. Machines should be able to identify the relationship between the label and the object through the syntax and if objects without labels exist, a failure statement can be flagged up.

procedure.1: Check that all interactive form components are correctly labeled.

examples.1: [This CodePen example](https://codepen.io/sushma-io/pen/zYbOREe) clearly has all interactive elements within the form correctly labeled and additionally goes the extra step by using input types to help reduce the chances of errors occurring during data entry.

techniques.title: Reduce issues within data entry with manual third-party content
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.10 Validate form errors and account for tooling requirements](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#validate-form-errors-and-account-for-tooling-requirements).

description.1: Provide a mechanism in which users can easily take content from third-party sources and use it within your product or service. Techniques such as the ability to paste into forms or the ability to drag and drop can act as shortcuts to avoid retyping or recreating (using system resources) which may be energy-intensive or time-intensive for the user.
description.2: Identifying mechanisms that may prevent the ability to import third-party content such as blocking pasting content or disabling the ability to drag and drop should be detected and flagged (unless a reason for this can be justified within the code). Mechanisms that aid the ability to import third-party content such as import or paste buttons should be actively encouraged.

procedure.1: Check that the ability to paste content is uninhibited (no onpaste="return false;").
procedure.2: Check that the ability to drag and drop third-party content can be achieved successfully.
procedure.3: Check that import options are provided if the above two options are unavailable or fail.

examples.1: These CodePen examples of [log in](https://codepen.io/colorlib/pen/rxddKy) and [registration](https://codepen.io/RajRajeshDn/pen/QWwypRy) forms do not inhibit the user from pasting content from third-party sources which allows for fast data entry if the information is stored elsewhere.

techniques.title: Ensure that the required HTML elements are included
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.11 Structure metadata for machine readability](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#structure-metadata-for-machine-readability).

description.1: Ensure that minimum required features are present to render a website or application correctly. This includes a Doctype and a series of core HTML elements. While a page can technically render without them it is considered bad practice to not include these features.
description.2: For machine testability, the ability to identify a DocType (and the version of HTML being rendered), plus ensuring that the necessary base HTML elements are present is script detectable. This can be done via the validation process, manually, or automated to ensure pages render correctly and avoid triggering quirks mode (that will affect the visual rendering of the website or application).

procedure.1: Check that the document includes a well-formed DocType.
procedure.2: Check that the page or application includes the required HTML elements.
procedure.3: Check that the page or application includes valid links to CSS and JavaScript assets (optional).
procedure.4: Check that the HTML includes the viewport META element for handheld devices.

examples.1: Courtney Thomas back in 2018 [created a great article](https://medium.com/@cortneythomas/laymans-coding-what-is-the-minimum-html-you-need-for-a-website-eda987b02622) that showcased the minimum HTML that is required for any website or application (though [as Josh Buchea notes](https://htmlhead.dev/), the viewport meta tag should also be there).

techniques.title: Provide relevant metadata using a recognized scheme
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.11 Structure metadata for machine readability](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#structure-metadata-for-machine-readability).

description.1: Provide the necessary metadata within the head of your website or application to ensure that search engines and social networks can index your content correctly. You can use several different mechanisms to achieve this as several different formatting schemes have been provided over the years and they have varying levels of support by different search providers.
description.2: To enhance the findability of your content (which will reduce time being wasted by users trying to locate you), having a well-formatted series of metadata is critical. As such, testing should focus on determining whether basic meta tags are used or if another format is being used to serve data. Once detected, identify if the tags are recognized, if they are not in common use or have been deprecated by a provider, it is worth requesting removal for the data savings.

procedure.1: Check that the HTML document contains a description META element of [between 50 and 150 characters](https://moz.com/learn/seo/meta-description).
procedure.2: Check that the HTML document contains additional metadata from a recognized scheme.
procedure.3: Check that the necessary social media metadata exists within the HTML head.

examples.1: The WHATWG not only has within the [HTML specification](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/semantics.html) a list of recognized elements that can provide contextual information about the page, but it also has a wiki that lists [proprietary META tags](https://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/MetaExtensions).
examples.2: Many social networks take advantage of the [OpenGraph Protocol](https://ogp.me/) including [Facebook](https://developers.facebook.com/docs/sharing/webmasters) and [X (formally Twitter)](https://developer.x.com/en/docs/x-for-websites/cards/overview/markup) in the HTML head. [Mastodon](https://joinmastodon.org/verification) uses the rel="me" attribute to identify websites with owners.

techniques.title: Ensure content is structured using Microdata
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.11 Structure metadata for machine readability](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#structure-metadata-for-machine-readability).

description.1: Provide mechanisms for search engines and social networks (and sometimes even users and web browsers!) to take context-rich content from your website or application and re-use it for the benefit of your product or service elsewhere. Structuring your content successfully can take place (like metadata) using one of several formats.
description.2: Because microdata uses hooks that attach to existing HTML to make it easy to identify (for search engines and third-parties), this will also make it easy to identify for machine testability. Using a pattern library of these various structural features you can not only show users how content could be used but using heuristics identify other content that might benefit from it.

procedure.1: Check that content is correctly marked up using microdata, microformats, etc.
procedure.2: Check for external RDFa assets that may contain rich metadata.

examples.1: [Schema](https://schema.org/) is a database of common patterns that have been formed using microdata. It is a huge library and could be potentially helpful in describing certain components in a way that search engines can recognize.

techniques.title: Ensure CSS preference media queries are correctly applied
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.12 Use sustainability beneficial user preference media queries](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#use-sustainability-beneficial-user-preference-media-queries).

description.1: Provide mechanisms through CSS that adhere to the user's preferences regarding how they may choose to browse a website or application. While some queries that exist in the language will hold little sustainability value, others could have PPP benefits through accessibility (societal factors), or environmental (reducing hardware or data usage).
description.2: Each of the preference queries can be machine-identified through scripts and therefore can be tested against firstly for browser support, and secondly that the project provides some kind of environmental consequence for using the query that will benefit the user and/or the ecosystem. The value of such queries being applied could be measured by triggering or emulating them.

procedure.1: Check for preference queries and that the effect they produce is beneficial.
procedure.2: Check for manual override toggles or preferences within the page.
procedure.3: Check for alternative styles if paged media or scripting is disabled.

examples.1: [Hidde de Vries](https://hidde.blog/) has a dark mode toggle that using a mixture of CSS preference queries and JavaScript allows dark or light mode to either be user-triggered or run at the default (it is non-invasively implemented).
examples.2: [These examples](https://webkit.org/blog-files/prefers-reduced-motion/prm.htm) provided by the Webkit team showcase how reduced motion (when enabled) can prevent excess movement. Though a toggle ([such as this by Michelle Barker](https://codepen.io/smashingmag/pen/porEQLB)) could provide [added use-cases](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/10/respecting-users-motion-preferences/).

techniques.title: Test against network speeds and visual resolution breakpoints
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.13 Ensure layouts work for different devices and requirements](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#ensure-layouts-work-for-different-devices-and-requirements).

description.1: Ensure that your product or service can be classified as device-adaptable (responsively designed) to hopefully assure the widest remit of device types, and at least some degree of visual compatibility with your website or application. While there are many ways to approach this task, this technique is focused on connection speeds and the potential window size.
description.2: Because connection speeds can vary based on a whole range of factors (and cannot be aligned with averages due to location, mobile vs home, connection quality, etc), multiple speed ranges should be machine tested against. The same can be said for window sizes as while resolutions are common to certain devices, browsers can be resized, and unusual device types do also exist therefore CSS fluid scaling and visual breakpoints should be utilized.

procedure.1: Check that the website or application performs well on a variety of network speeds.
procedure.2: Check that the product or service visually does not break when resized at multiple window sizes.

examples.1: [WebPageTest](https://www.webpagetest.org/) allows you to check how a product or service will perform at different speeds (including custom profiles you set up). Running such tests can identify if a product or service takes too long to load.
examples.2: Browser developer tools can test a website at various dimensions (on desktop) and by manually resizing the browser window with the developer tools open (and rulers toggled in Firefox), you can identify breakpoints where the design of the site requires code solutions.

techniques.title: Provide progressive enhancement feature testing within projects
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.13 Ensure layouts work for different devices and requirements](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#ensure-layouts-work-for-different-devices-and-requirements).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for providing features within your product or service only if they are supported and if not, providing alternatives. This can be done using feature detection and progressive enhancement which should be used as a priority over graceful degradation (as it is better to add useful extras rather than patch-critical - but broken content).
description.2: Machine testability for feature testing should identify any code within the product or service that relies upon newer functionality lacking a level of web browser support (either in competing products or older versions), testing should occur and errors should be handled. Furthermore, if technologies are not supported, the fallback mechanism should allow a basic project to run.

procedure.1: Check that the website or application can function if JavaScript is disabled.
procedure.2: Check that the page is still functional if an older browser version with older JavaScript and CSS version is used.
procedure.3: Check that the product or service is still functional if CSS is disabled.
procedure.4: Check that the product or service is still functional if images or media are disabled.

tests.expectedResults: Expectation of the above is dependent on the task but should aim to be true unless necessary.

examples.1: Jeremy Keith's website ([Adactio](https://adactio.com/)) is a great example of progressive enhancement in action. It works if JavaScript, CSS, or even images are disabled (though naturally, the visuals can suffer as a result!).

techniques.title: Configure your project around carbon-aware situations
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.13 Ensure layouts work for different devices and requirements](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#ensure-layouts-work-for-different-devices-and-requirements).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for identifying when the project might be at its most resource or energy-intensive (either at the consumer level or the system level - or both), and then decision make to delay or alter when a heavy script or operation occurs to perform it when there are fewer users or when the user is causing less hardware intensive activity.
description.2: For machine testability, this could be particularly tricky to implement as it will rely on data to which the project owner will need to gain access such as when user numbers are at their lowest (or when the task can be achieved at its quickest). This may require internal access, but if granted the use of such data could allow for redesigning the site to perform better during busy periods.

procedure.1: Check if operations can be built to function using carbon-aware technologies or resources.
procedure.2: Check if operations can be processed or shifted to occur during less carbon-intensive periods.

examples.1: [Electricity Maps](https://app.electricitymaps.com/) provides an application that could be utilized to help make decisions as to where data is being served (based upon the intensity and level of low-carbon energy being offered in particular regions).

techniques.title: Provide low-impact, delayed, or alternate methods of interaction
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.13 Ensure layouts work for different devices and requirements](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#ensure-layouts-work-for-different-devices-and-requirements).

description.1: Provide a low impact mechanism for interacting with a website or application. These indirect methods such as syndication feeds or the browser reader view can even eliminate the heavy impact of rendering that can affect hardware. This technique is most useful when it can be easily recognized by users and can be used instead of having to visit the main website or application. In terms of machine testability, if these low-impact techniques use a common pattern and that pattern can be easily identified within the source code then naturally it can be identified as such and can be marked as meeting the criteria.
description.2: Also consider those not using a screen as a primary method of browsing to ensure they have an equal browsing experience. This is primarily due to screens being a high emitter of emissions in terms of energy usage, but also with the increase in speech-powered devices, the need for support mechanisms to be in place has increased in recent years.
description.3: Detection of such support can be clearly identified with good semantics and high-quality content as a foundation, however for machine testability, thresholds such as having a speech style sheet in place (that can help with issues around pronunciation and tone) and testing projects within text browsers for fundamental mechanical issues are critical to establish a pass.

procedure.1: Check for low-impact interaction methods such as QR codes, smartwatch layouts, or voice assistant tooling.
procedure.2: Check for a speech style sheet for indicators to clarify pronunciation issues.
procedure.3: Check that your website or application functions correctly in a text-only environment.

examples.1: Quick Response (QR) codes are a great example of objects that can be included not only online but offline in branding to trigger both links and in-app actions with only the impact of rendering the object (or printing it).
examples.2: Smartwatches may have some Internet connectivity. Due to the small screen size, they will have a low energy output but also a small battery so having a low-fidelity version of a website can be really useful.
examples.3: The [Lynx text browser](https://lynx.invisible-island.net/) is one of the oldest maintained browsers on the Internet and it can be particularly useful in identifying issues around keyboard navigation and non-visual browsing when features are unavailable.
examples.4: This [article from Smashing Magazine](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2020/12/making-websites-accessible/) describes in detail how websites and applications can make their work easier for non-visual devices such as speech environments (like cars and smart speakers) to access.

techniques.title: Optimize a codebase through rewriting for performance
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.14 Use standards-based JavaScript and APIs](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#use-standards-based-javascript-and-apis).

description.1: Improve the quality of JavaScript code by examining the contents and identifying any issues that could be deemed a matter of sustainability which could trigger a large load upon hardware resources (and thus put a strain on battery charge cycles). In addition to this, matters of accessibility and performance with such code can be considered.
description.2: To meet the success criteria, rewriting for performance should only be done if the act does not cost more in effort (and creator impact) than it gains in impact. For machine testability, it is critical that such actions within scripting use tools at their disposal (libraries, patterns, even AI) to heuristically identify any issues that may require resolution within the project's source code.

procedure.1: Check that existing code has been rewritten to be less process intensive, etc.
procedure.2: Check that any existing tooling is considered sustainable and/or performant.
procedure.3: Check if JavaScript frameworks can be replaced with others that are more performant.
procedure.4: If frameworks can be replaced, check that they are replaced.

examples.1: Solid.js author Ryan Carniato created [this thoughtful post](https://javascript.plainenglish.io/how-we-wrote-the-fastest-javascript-ui-frameworks-a96f2636431e) in 2019 about how they went about integrating web performance in their framework-building processes. It is based on a widely recognized JavaScript study.
examples.2: The team at Astro [used open data to examine](https://astro.build/blog/2023-web-framework-performance-report/) the performance ratings of various competing JavaScript frameworks to identify the differences between physical and real-world metrics (there are lots of useful charts).

techniques.title: Ensure JavaScript APIs are correctly applied
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.14 Use standards-based JavaScript and APIs](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#use-standards-based-javascript-and-apis).

description.1: Provide mechanisms through JavaScript that minimize the user's energy consumption by either optimizing the performance of the website or application itself or improving functionality in such a way that it reduces the utilization of resources when they are not required by the user. Some JavaScript APIs can have explicit sustainability benefits, while others may improve other PPP benefits through accessibility (societal factors).
description.2: Each of the JavaScript APIs can be machine-identified through scripts and therefore can be tested against firstly for browser support, and secondly that the project provides some environmental consequence for using the script that will benefit the user and/or the ecosystem. The value of such scripts could be measured by triggering or emulating them.

procedure.1: Check for JavaScript APIs and that the effect they produce is beneficial.
procedure.2: Check that the API has enough support to be progressively implemented.
procedure.3: Check that the implementation cost is not greater than the amount it offsets.
procedure.4: If the API is dependent on third-parties, ensure they are sustainable and resilient.

examples.1: [MDN Provides a list of Web APIs](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API) that can be implemented ([with varying levels of browser support](https://whatwebcando.today/). Some of these provide enhanced functionality to the end-user, and others may tuned to provide the ecodesign benefits that will give your product or service an edge.
examples.2: Custom APIs such as our [WSG JSON API](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/guidelines.json) ([source](https://github.com/w3c/sustainableweb-wsg/blob/main/guidelines.json)) can be used within your product or service to provide actionable sustainability information to your users that is maintained and kept up-to-date.

techniques.title: Ensure all vulnerabilities are removed and code is Linted
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.15 Ensure that your code is secure](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#ensure-that-your-code-is-secure).

description.1: Scan the website or application's code for issues that may otherwise potentially leave a product or service vulnerable to exploitation. This will not only include first-party code that is created by the project owners but third-party tooling imported. Any third-party library or framework found to contain harmful code should be removed before production.
description.2: Because this can occur at both the client-side and server-side internal access may be required if server-side scanning is wished to be included within machine testability, however within the scope of the success criteria, if internal access is not available or permitted, testing the code using known methods and scanning client-side code for harmful techniques should help with passing.

procedure.1: Check the product or service for vulnerabilities within your code, ensuring they are resolved.

examples.1: RayGun [provides a great article](https://raygun.com/blog/js-security-vulnerabilities-best-practices/) about vulnerabilities and best practices when working with JavaScript. Some of the things mentioned are covered within the WSG in other sections, all others can be followed here.
examples.2: [Snyk](https://snyk.io/) is one of the most well-known providers of data regarding code vulnerabilities. They can be integrated within existing tooling or you can browse their [database of known security issues](https://security.snyk.io/) to be aware of.

techniques.title: Identify and remove unused packages and dependencies
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.16 Use dependencies appropriately and ensure maintenance](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#use-dependencies-appropriately-and-ensure-maintenance).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for identifying if a library or framework is currently in use and if not, remove the said tooling and its unused dependencies from the production code. This will help reduce the PPP burden of the website as less bloat will reach the user which can have a large impact if they are on a low-powered device or a restricted data plan.
description.2: For machine testability, internal access will be required to determine if web developers or creators will require specific tooling within a project. If internal access is given, the package.json file is an ideal place to locate the packages being requested and these can be compared against the public-facing website to identify redundancy in the toolchain process.

procedure.1: Check if a package.json has been submitted for identifying packages.
procedure.2: If so, use that. Otherwise, check the source code for potential orphan references.

examples.1: An application that removes functionality due to poor uptake no longer requires certain packages to contain scripts that were dedicated to running that function alone. Such dependencies have become redundant.

techniques.title: Implement modularized or lightweight frameworks and libraries
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.16 Use dependencies appropriately and ensure maintenance](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#use-dependencies-appropriately-and-ensure-maintenance).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for determining how much of a library of framework you require for your website or application to function, and then requesting just that modularized segment to reduce the overall payload and load on the user's hardware during rendering. This is especially critical for third-party scripting but is also useful for CSS. Reduce the overhead of libraries and frameworks which may be used by the product or service but could be offered through lighter or less production-heavy alternatives.
description.2: Machine testability should attempt to identify when third-party libraries are present within a codebase and if that framework or library supports the ability to load a lightweight or modular version of its features (thereby only loading what you require, when you require it), ensure that the project in question does so rather than loading an un-optimal "fully-loaded" version of the project.
