description.3: This will potentially require testability tooling to have both a library of existing frameworks and libraries - including smaller single-purpose ones (with the functionality they contain) and the ability to identify within code the feature set that is being utilized by a product or service. Through isolating in-use capabilities, better recommendations can be made which could reduce the project payload.

procedure.1: Check the package size to determine at what size breaking into modular components should occur.
procedure.2: Check the function sizes to identify if refactoring to smaller functions should also occur.
procedure.3: Check if CSS libraries could be replaced with smaller alternatives or custom code.
procedure.4: Check if JavaScript frameworks could be replaced with smaller alternatives or native code.
procedure.5: If replacements can be made, then replacements should be introduced.

examples.1: [Bundlephobia](https://bundlephobia.com/) and [pkg-size](https://pkg-size.dev/) allow you to find the true size of a package on NPM by calculating not just the size of the item you wish to install but all of the dependencies the item requires to function.
examples.2: [You Might Not Need jQuery](https://youmightnotneedjquery.com/) provides information about potential replacements for the longstanding JavaScript framework that could be more performant and lightweight while offering the same functionality.
examples.3: [You (Might) Don't Need jQuery](https://github.com/camsong/You-Dont-Need-jQuery) showcases a series of examples of how pre-existing jQuery functionality can now be replaced with native functionality and as such, the framework could be eliminated.
examples.4: [MicroJS](http://microjs.com/#) is a list of tiny JavaScript frameworks that serve a single purpose and if you utilize a single large framework for this very reason, could be swapped out to reduce the environmental impact of your work.

techniques.title: Ensure that dependencies are verified as up-to-date
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.16 Use dependencies appropriately and ensure maintenance](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#use-dependencies-appropriately-and-ensure-maintenance).

description.1: Ensure that the deliverables are current and up-to-date, thereby providing any necessary security patches or bug fixes that are required to remain operational. This is especially true when a website or application is dependent on third-party libraries or frameworks and has a complex toolchain. As such, verifying the maintenance status of work is critical.
description.2: To machine test or verify the dependency chain of a project, the source code of a project should identify (by filename or URL) the project and version. If during the tree shaking or production process all notifications of what third-party code has been used have been removed, internal access will be required to access the package.json (except heuristic fingerprinting of packages).

procedure.1: Check if a package.json has been submitted for identifying packages.
procedure.2: If so, use that. Otherwise, check the source code for package version data.
procedure.3: Check that all packages are at least non-breaking (minor) current if not major release current releases.

examples.1: As you would expect, the [jQuery project website](https://jquery.com/) uses the latest version of the jQuery framework. Because it is a regularly maintained project and can afford rapid update cycles, it stays current and up-to-date.

techniques.title: Provide the expected website assets in your base directory
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.17 Include expected and beneficial files](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#include-expected-and-beneficial-files).

description.1: Ensure that the non-HTML files that are expected to be located within the base directory of a website can firstly be found and secondly are correctly formatted (using the right syntax) and match the expectations of the product or service that requires them to benefit the user with a better user experience, increased accessibility, and sustainability.
description.2: For machine testability, tooling should aim to identify that the listed files are provided (if not flag these justifying the need for their inclusion). If they are included they should be examined to ensure they are semantically correct, especially if they are formed using a strict language such as XML. If they fail to validate correctly errors should constitute a failure to meet the success criteria.

procedure.1: Check the base directory for a favicon in 16×16, 32×32, and 48×48 format.
procedure.2: Check the base directory for a well-formed robots.txt document.
procedure.3: Check the base directory for a well-formed opensearch.xml and sitemap.xml file.
procedure.4: Check the base directory for a well-formed site.webmanifest document.
procedure.5: Check that the links contained within these documents do not contain errors.

examples.1: Amazon has a highly recognizable brand and they [provide a favicon](https://www.amazon.com/favicon.ico) in the base of their website so that when people visit them, their icon will show correctly in the top left of the tab or window (browser dependent).
examples.2: Developer tool Can I Use [provide an opensearch.xml file](https://caniuse.com/opensearch.xml) in the base of their website so that if people visit their project, users can rapidly search the website in the future using a keyword and tab combination.
examples.3: [Google has a robots.txt file](https://www.google.com/robots.txt) that identifies to search engines what pages should be included within search results. You can also look to [Web Robots Pages](https://www.robotstxt.org/robotstxt.html) and [Google Search Central](https://developers.google.com/crawling/docs/robots-txt/robots-txt-spec?hl=en) for implementation inspiration.

techniques.title: Provide beneficial plaintext website assets in the expected locations
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.17 Include expected and beneficial files](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#include-expected-and-beneficial-files).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for adding useful contextual information to a website or application within recognized locations in plaintext format (so that it does not impact the rest of the product or service). These standardized formats each have a defined beneficial purpose and are considered to be low-impact (sustainably speaking) so are safe to include.
description.2: This technique is most useful when the assets are formatted as per their specification for purposes of readability, it is how individuals and machines will be expected to understand them. For machine testability, using heuristics to scan for recognized features within the text should help you identify the instructions or any features of note that could be weighed in calculations.

procedure.1: If you have advertising, check that the base directory contains a well-formed ads.txt document.
procedure.2: Check that the base directory contains a well-formed security.txt and robots.txt document.
procedure.3: Check that the base directory contains a well-formed carbon.txt and humans.txt document (optional).

examples.1: [WordPress has an ads.txt file](https://wordpress.com/ads.txt) at the base of their website, that contains details of the advertisers they work with (and tries to increase transparency by revealing where impressions are purchased and resold).
examples.2: Web Developer Sarah Tamsin has a [fun example of a humans.txt file](https://sarahtamsin.com/humans.txt) that provides some witty content and a few basic details about them (plus an ASCII image that makes for a nice easter egg bonus feature).
examples.3: The security.txt specification writers have [created a basic example](https://securitytxt.org/.well-known/security.txt) of what could be included within the file. As you can see from the example, the location of the document differs from other plaintext examples.

techniques.title: Encourage the use of more sustainable creation toolchains
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.18 Use the most efficient solution for your service](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#use-the-most-efficient-solution-for-your-service).

description.1: Provide a mechanism of choice when creators decide how to build their product or service. This technique aims to identify how they created their product or service (if possible) and make recommendations based on the sustainability of such methods. Build steps and tooling add additional complexity to a project and this should be weighed against other factors (such as individual/team ability) to enable sustainable creation toolchains.
description.2: For machine testability, internal access may be required if no traces of the creation tool have been left in the production code. If the production code does however contain fingerprints of the tool that created it, recommendations can be made to prioritize static over dynamic and flat-static over generated-static as reducing the processing effort on servers and client machines is meaningful.

procedure.1: Check for the tool used for creation and determine its sustainability.
procedure.2: If it has a low impact, continue. Otherwise, flag for replacement.

examples.1: [Jekyll](https://jekyllrb.com/) is one of many solutions that exist as a solution for producing a website - in this case, it uses markdown and bundles the plaintext into a finalized pure HTML state (which should have a low carbon output).

techniques.title: Test all third-party resources for sustainability impacts
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.18 Use the most efficient solution for your service](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#use-the-most-efficient-solution-for-your-service).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for testing third-party plugins, extensions, and themes (if such devices are used within a product or service's creation process) for any sustainability impacts they may have. These often are included within CMS software and are external assets that can add overheads to the website or application being rendered.
description.2: For machine testability, many CMS products provide trace details of included features within the source code of a page (as conditional comments) due to these having to be loaded as third-party resources. Internal access may be required to get a full picture of everything being loaded. Third-party resources should be tested against the WSG separately to identify sustainability issues.

procedure.1: Check if any third-party resources exist within the page or application.
procedure.2: If internal access is required to verify resource usage, grant it.
procedure.3: Check that component against the WSG for its sustainability compliance.
procedure.4: Check if high-impact third-party resources offer self-hosted alternatives.
procedure.5: Check that self-hosted alternatives are used if provided.

examples.1: When using WordPress as their primary content management system, they often want to have a distinctive layout for their blog or website. As such they will install a custom theme, and its code with sustainability impacts will be imported into the total bundle size. So be careful what you choose!

techniques.title: Ensure the latest version of a syntax language is being used
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.19 Use the latest stable language version](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#use-the-latest-stable-language-version).

description.1: Ensure that the product or service is making use of the latest version of the chosen syntax language. As with keeping dependencies up-to-date, having the latest version of a syntax language can have sustainability benefits in terms of performance and security enhancements as well as useful, optimized new features so it is worthwhile.
description.2: For machine testability, it will be difficult to verify the latest version of a syntax language is being used because, for security reasons (to avoid exploitation), most servers will not give out such information. As such, internal access will be required or a mixture of feature detection, source code examination, and the potential for asking the user of the tooling questions to establish versions.

procedure.1: Check that the version of a programming language being used is the latest.

examples.1: PHP provides a list of the [supported](https://www.php.net/supported-versions.php) and [unsupported](https://www.php.net/releases/index.php) versions of their programming language. You should be able to manage updates and upgrades within a hosting provider's control panel (if required).

techniques.title: Publicly disclose relevant sustainability metrics to users
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [4.1 Use sustainable hosting](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#use-sustainable-hosting).

description.1: Ensure that anyone who wishes to compile an impact statement (as a consumer of your services) based on conditions such as PUE, WUE, and CUE can calculate the necessary energy utilization of a provider using each of the available data based upon any factors required. Making important metrics publicly visible to both customers and users, increases awareness, reduces the potential for greenwashing, and allows service providers to report with proof of compliance.
description.2: For machine testability, this would require each customer account (of a hosting provider) to be equipped with a publicly visible stats page indicating resource utilization, including useful information on factors like CPU, GPU, RAM, and data usage, plus a calculation on equivalent water or other consumable resource utilization. This can be linked to from within the service status page. In addition, the methodology behind the calculations should also be provided in a centralized location.

procedure.1: Check that the provider has made available relevant hosting metrics publicly.
procedure.2: Check that the PUE, WUE, and CUE are each listed for each data center.
procedure.3: Check that individual servers provide live CPU, GPU, RAM, and data use tracking.
procedure.4: Check that logging of past values over time is provided for calculating emissions.

examples.1: [OVHCloud](https://corporate.ovhcloud.com/en/sustainability/environment/) and [Opcore](https://pue.dc5.opcore.eu/en/) both showcase different ways of displaying data about their environmental impact and notably, the factors that make up that number (with calculations and individual metrics provided). Both dashboards and sustainability panels are equally useful tools for showcasing such information.
examples.2: A service provider could make the internal resource usage stats page that comes with many hosting packages publicly visible (upon request of the website or application provider), and include sustainability data within.

techniques.title: Ensure that the project is hosted on a sustainable platform
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [4.1 Use sustainable hosting](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#use-sustainable-hosting).

description.1: Verify that the product or service is being served through a sustainable provider. If the hosting provider (for example) generates its electricity from low-carbon energy and can document other intensity reduction techniques (such as using natural cooling and offering auto-scaling packages), this can contribute towards passing the success criteria.
description.2: Because many factors can go towards how sustainable a provider is, machine testing will need to be vigilant in accounting for several factors. As such, using an established directory of sustainable hosts could be one way to pass or fail, or running validation checks against factors that affect the sustainability of services could be another (this may require internal access or knowledge).

procedure.1: Check that the hosting provider has a sustainability statement.
procedure.2: Check that the hosting is powered by 100% low-carbon energy.
procedure.3: Check that the hosting platform does not use carbon credits to offset its energy requirements.
procedure.4: Check for recognized green initiatives that the platform may be subscribed to.
procedure.5: Check if sustainability-related keywords or claims are made.
procedure.6: Check that any claims made are verified with supporting evidence.

examples.1: The [Green Web Directory](https://www.thegreenwebfoundation.org/tools/directory/) from the Green Software Foundation provides a list of sustainable providers of hosting (based on their own criteria). If a service is listed in a reputable list as this, it may meet the success criteria.
examples.2: [Krystal](https://krystal.io/green) is an example of a provider offering detailed information about their sustainability process including their B-Corporation status, and the schemes they have signed up with to validate and reinforce their claims.

techniques.title: Ensure that the project uses a sustainable domain registrar
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [4.1 Use sustainable hosting](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#use-sustainable-hosting).

description.1: Ensure that emissions reports are published, with adequate frequency, considering (if possible) changes to DNS, subdomain allocation, multiple domain ownership, or other conditions that may impact the scope results. Also, be sure to provide calculations on an individual and collective domain level (where situations allow) to enable the best overview possible of total impact and most impactful domains. Having these metrics available for customers will increase public awareness, and allow registrants to meet reporting obligations as part of their compliance requirements.
description.2: For machine testability customer accounts should have a method to view changes in emissions, this would require an account (of a registrar) to be made accessible within tooling or for generalized statistics that account for the total amount of users to be made publicly visible (so averages can be used). This would help estimate and account for the impact of domain use based on TLD choice and other factors that will be relevant to the measurement criteria. The methodology behind the calculations should also be provided in a centralized location.

procedure.1: Check that the provider has made available relevant impact metrics publicly.
procedure.2: Account for factors that may affect domain impact (such as number of domains in use).
procedure.3: Check that logging of past values over time is provided for calculating emissions.

examples.1: The [Eco Registry](https://go.eco/news/climate-reporting-for-eco-domains/) provides climate reports for customers, allowing them to get an estimate of the emissions from operating the domain name over the lifetime of the registration period.

techniques.title: Provide caching responses to optimize page reloads
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [4.2 Optimize caching and support offline access](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#optimize-caching-and-support-offline-access).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for websites and applications to ensure that content is cached for the correct length of time, with the intention of reusability. Because certain types of content will change and need to be reloaded more frequently than others, it makes sense to cache those that change the least for the longest period (to reduce data transfer rates).
description.2: For machine testability, identifying cache response times for various file formats can be done by checking the cache-control headers for various files as they are requested from the server. If the length of time the content is being held does not appear to be long enough (or is too long for dynamic content), then recommendations can be made to improve the used formula.

procedure.1: Check the cache-control header of each file has the correct length set.

examples.1: For individuals who use content management systems, some plugins offer [automatic caching management](https://www.wpbeginner.com/plugins/best-wordpress-caching-plugins/). They each have a range of features but essentially allow you to automate the caching process.

techniques.title: Identify the potential for PWAs and other useful features
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [4.2 Optimize caching and support offline access](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#optimize-caching-and-support-offline-access).

description.1: Identify if techniques could be used to increase the performance within the user experience. Examples of this could include identifying if cookies could (and should) be used within an interface or if the website or application could be transformed into a progressive web application to provide advantages (project-wide) such as offline availability.
description.2: Machine testability to identify existing features is relatively straightforward as it simply requires identifying through the source code where cookies, local database requests, service, or web workers are implemented and ensuring that they are both proportionate and correctly marked up. If these do not exist it will require analyzing the page (or components) for potential opportunities for use.

procedure.1: Check if cookies are in use and, whether they can be added, removed, or replaced.
procedure.2: Check if local data storage is being used and, whether it can be added, removed, or replaced.
procedure.3: Check if a PWA or other worker functions are in use and, whether they can be added or removed.
procedure.4: If a PWA exists, check for a well-formed manifest file, an icon, and semantically correct JavaScript.

examples.1: [Gmail](https://workspace.google.com/intl/en_us/gmail/) makes sense as a progressive web application because if the Internet connection is lost (at any point), being able to continue using certain features without losing your progress is critical to functionality.
examples.2: [NPM](https://www.npmjs.com/login) saves information about your membership login locally (as do many other providers) to avoid needing to re-enter your details repeatedly. This is a useful feature as it increases a product's perceived performance.

techniques.title: Ensure that files are compressed correctly before serving
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [4.3 Reduce data transfer with compression](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#reduce-data-transfer-with-compression).

description.1: Provide a mechanism to serve content correctly using a recognized encoding method to reduce the payload size of websites and applications. While this means there will be an additional rendering effort on the client-side (decoding the file), the increased speed in loading such files has an PPP benefit that justifies the added effort.
description.2: For machine testability, identifying content encoding methods for file formats can be done by checking the content-encoding headers for various files as they are requested from the server. This can be achieved on an individual basis or through server configuration files. If the content is not being encoded (unless it has been encoded at the source and no further optimization can be made), recommendations can be made to use a compatible compression technique.

procedure.1: Check all text assets for content-encoding headers to verify compression takes place.
procedure.2: Check content-encoding headers work for not in-use formats for forward-compatibility efforts.
procedure.3: Check if the compression method used is the most optimal type available.

examples.1: The [Solid Chocolate Company](https://www.solidchocolates.com/) serves all of their content using GZIP compression headers ensuring that data gets to the user as quickly as possible (in addition to compressing image and media assets at source).

techniques.title: Compress all assets that can be optimized before CMS submission
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [4.3 Reduce data transfer with compression](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#reduce-data-transfer-with-compression).

description.1: Provide additional mechanisms in place for non-technical users so that the potential for compression is just only checked once files are in place within a website or application's structure (uploaded), but also during the upload process, thereby taking the opportunity to meet sustainability criteria on-the-fly as part of the content management system.
description.2: To pass this success criterion, a CMS (or SaaS) would need to take assets that are uploaded and identify compression that could be applied either by changing file formats or by applying algorithms to it (or both). If improvements can be made, these should replace the original files by default. Machines can verify this is occurring by identifying if the best format is used or if further compression could be applied (this could form part of a tools sustainability rating).

procedure.1: Check that all assets are optimized for the web in size, format, and quality before publication.
procedure.2: If assets have been altered prior to publication, check users are pre-warned of any changes.
procedure.3: Check that the files published are the optimized versions (more than one may be necessary).
procedure.4: Check if a CMS will be necessary or useful and if so, ensure static assets are uploaded there.

examples.1: Tooling such as [Squoosh](https://squoosh.app/) and [SVGOMG](https://jakearchibald.github.io/svgomg/) can help website creators find optimizations before uploading or submitting content to a product or service (other services offer APIs that can be integrated into tooling).
examples.2: There is a [whole range of plugins available](https://blog.hubspot.com/website/best-wordpress-image-optimization-plugins) for WordPress (and other CMS products) that can assist with automatic image optimization. This can help reduce the environmental impact they have before public visibility.

techniques.title: Provide custom error pages to handle unexpected events
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [4.4 Setup necessary error pages and redirection links](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#setup-necessary-error-pages-and-redirection-links).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for if and when users land on a region of your website or application that either does not exist or appears to be broken. Such encounters can be disorientating and without useful signposting and interactions to get users out of such events, additional unnecessary page loads or support requests can occur leading to emissions.
description.2: Machine testing for errors can simply involve triggering the events and identifying if the page loaded in response is one that is server-generated or one that has been customized by the website or application. If it has been customized does it provide useful resources to help resolve the problem? This could be measured using analytics (which may require internal access).

procedure.1: Check that the website or application has a custom set of pages to respond to errors.
procedure.2: Check that each error status type has its own page and unique situation handling.
procedure.3: Check that such pages provide signposting to resolve the error they encountered.
procedure.4: Check that existing links to navigation related pages remain fully functional.
procedure.5: Check that links to customer support are provided when solutions do not work.

examples.1: HubSpot has [some great examples](https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33766/10-clever-website-error-messages-from-creative-companies.aspx) of 404 (page not found) error pages showcasing good user experience design in addition to providing a few helpful pieces of advice regarding how they should function.
examples.2: This [GitHub package](https://github.com/HttpErrorPages/HttpErrorPages) provides support for multiple servers and offers a decent boilerplate for anyone wishing to ensure coverage for a wide range of common errors that can occur during site browsing.

techniques.title: Resolve all anchor references which trigger errors or redirects
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [4.4 Setup necessary error pages and redirection links](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#setup-necessary-error-pages-and-redirection-links).

description.1: Reduce the amount of wasted rendering effort on the part of users and users of a website or application by ensuring that products and services regularly and routinely check that all of the links within pages are correct and do not need to be updated. This can be a common issue amongst large sites or those with older content (as the material can be moved or disappear online), so links must be updated to reflect this).
description.2: Regarding machine testability, verifying that all links within domains and subdomains of a product or service are correctly linked to and do not resolve in redirect notices or server/missing (not found) errors is essential for meeting this success criterion as it showcases the currency of the content. It should also be noted that links apply equally to images, media, HTML head references, and other materials referenced within the page, not just content anchor links.

procedure.1: Check that no anchor reference or in-page reference contains links that do not resolve (server errors).
procedure.2: Check that no anchor reference or in-page reference contains dead (erroneous) links.
procedure.3: Check that no anchor reference or in-page reference contains redirection links.
procedure.4: Check that links to external websites do not result in forbidden errors.

examples.1: Open source products like [Link Checker](https://github.com/linkchecker/linkchecker) can verify the status of references across multiple pages. This can be a quick and easy way of locating issues that have built up across an entire product or service.
examples.2: W3C has a simple [web-based interface](https://validator.w3.org/checklink) for validating links for errors on a page-by-page basis which can be helpful if you do not want to have to install applications or self-host packages to run tests.

techniques.title: Check that pages have not been subjected to hijacking
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [4.6 Use automation wisely](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#use-automation-wisely).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for identifying compromised content within a page of a website or application. As having a secure product or service is critical to meeting the societal (people) aspect of PPP and compromised websites can place unnecessary burdens on hardware in certain circumstances, being able to identify and remove such materials is essential.
description.2: Machine testability for these events will require regular monitoring of pages for common features of hijacking events such as critical links suddenly redirecting outside of the primary domain, pages being redesigned with hacking notices, or simply being taken down and replaced with other data. Maintaining a library of established dangerous links, patterns, and features can help flag such issues.

procedure.1: Check links do not contain abnormalities such as significant or feature-critical external redirections.
procedure.2: Check pages do not contain tracking, mining, or advertising that has occurred suddenly.
procedure.3: Check pages do not contain closure, ransom, or hacking notices.
procedure.4: Check pages do not trigger sudden redirections to other domains.
procedure.5: Check the domain has not been included within a security firm or Google compromised lists.

examples.1: [Compromised websites](https://kinsta.com/blog/the-site-ahead-contains-malware/) may present in many forms, but if they are [detected by Google](https://transparencyreport.google.com/safe-browsing/search), the search giant will intercept the user before they get exposed to the problem code and present them with an error.

techniques.title: Ensure that stored data has a defined and reasonable expiry date
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [4.7 Define the frequency of data refreshes.](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#define-the-frequency-of-data-refreshes).

description.1: Ensure that mechanisms are in place to hold data for only as long as it is required. This will reduce redundancy from things like stale cookies, and it will also assist older devices that may have lower capacity disk space allowances by reducing the overall size of caches which will free up important space (that otherwise reduces performance).
description.2: Identifying technologies for stashing data for a set time such as cookies, local databases, or other methods can be machine-tested. It is also worth identifying techniques that may be slower performing and making recommendations based on such implementations. Otherwise, verify that an expiry date does exist and if time has elapsed (or no date exists), flag the issue.

procedure.1: Check the expiration date of locally stored data and if that date has exceeded, remove the data.
procedure.2: Check the expiration date of server-side stored data and if that date has elapsed, remove the information.
procedure.3: If no expiration date exists for client-side or server-side data, either add one or remove the data.

examples.1: Cookies are a classic example of data stored for a particular reason, but if they are left unchecked, accumulate in vast numbers. While they do not take up a lot of space, they still should be purged if no longer required.

techniques.title: Deliver content using the correct, most secure protocol
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [4.9 Consider the impact and requirements of data processing](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#consider-the-impact-and-requirements-of-data-processing).

description.1: Guarantee that users who experience a website or application will have their experience delivered using a secure delivery route. Transmitting data using non-secure means (now that SSL certificates can be obtained free of charge) should never occur as there are inherent risks that can otherwise be avoided during the browsing session.
description.2: Machine testing for protocol testing will involve examining that the page is being served across HTTPS in opposition to HTTP (there should not be an occasion where both are available, especially if dynamic or interactive content exists). Furthermore, insecure protocols for non-browsing usage should be tested to verify they are disabled and replaced (if required) with more secure options.

procedure.1: Check that the product or service is being delivered over HTTPS rather than HTTP.
procedure.2: Check that alternative protocol usage is only done using secure means.

examples.1: FTP is a classic example of a protocol that while disabled for browsing in several web browsers, could pose security issues if not blocked entirely. It should instead be replaced with SSH (preferred) or SFTP (at minimum).

techniques.title: Provide distributed access to static resources via a CDN
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [4.10 Use Content Delivery Networks (CDNs) appropriately](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#use-content-delivery-networks-cdns-appropriately).

description.1: Offer a mechanism for users to gain access to a static website or application assets in a location that is closer to them than the origin host. By utilizing a content delivery network, large media files, images, fonts, and other static assets can be distributed to regional locations so that users can access them quicker (as the route to the file is shorter).
description.2: Machine testing for content delivery networks should take into account the balance as to whether adding assets to multiple locations (for performance) incurs more of a sustainability cost than loading them quicker. If the value in faster loading is greater, and a CDN is in use, this qualifies as a pass. If no CDN is being used, or one is in use but the added value is neutral or negative, question its impact and whether the material should be instead hosted onsite.

procedure.1: Check the existing location of static resources on the existing website.
procedure.2: If they exist on the first-party domain, calculate the sustainability value of using a CDN.
procedure.3: Check if the value of using a CDN will be beneficial, if so use one.

examples.1: While it does not provide insights into sustainability, [CDN Compare](https://cdncomparison.com/) offers a great deal of context between several popular content delivery networks and the offerings they provide to help you make up your mind.

techniques.title: Ensure that the CDN and its chain of locations are sustainable
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [4.10 Use Content Delivery Networks (CDNs) appropriately](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#use-content-delivery-networks-cdns-appropriately).

description.1: Test the sustainability of the CDN against the WSG as a service provider as a third-party service in addition to any sustainability criteria and best practices that exist externally for infrastructure and hosting. This not only applies to the provider itself but to all of the nodes that it uses to supply distribution, and any third-parties it uses as part of its extended network. As such, calculating and vetting providers can be complex.
description.2: For machine testability, providers should have information about sustainability offered within a sustainability statement along with details of compliance being met plus any sustainability features they provide that enhance their service. If this information is publicly available (and uses recognized sources), it could be parsed by machine, otherwise, a sustainable provider list should be sourced.

procedure.1: Check if the CDN provider has a sustainability statement in place.
procedure.2: Check if the CDN provider meets any sustainability compliance obligations.
procedure.3: Check that CDN against the WSG for its sustainability compliance.
procedure.4: Check that the CDN supply network (nodes) are also as sustainable as the provider.

examples.1: [Akamai](https://www.akamai.com/resources/research-paper/akamai-2023-environmental-social-governance-report) (PDF) provides a yearly PPP report that showcases and documents all of the changes they have made towards becoming more sustainable. While they have not fully become sustainable, they are getting there.

techniques.title: Provide a copy of the product or service close to the user
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [4.10 Use Content Delivery Networks (CDNs) appropriately](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#use-content-delivery-networks-cdns-appropriately).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for mirroring the content (website or application) as close to the user as possible to reduce the loading time as effectively as possible. This can be done using CDNs or by analyzing metrics data and deciding based on the locale of users where the origin host choice would be best placed (both can be useful methods).
description.2: Machine testing for this requires internal access to analytics logs to determine where user locations are and from this identify the best location to place information (if a CDN is used, this may be automatically done on your behalf meeting compliance requirements). If no internal access or data is available, general statistics about Internet usage could help identify trends.

procedure.1: Check if you only serve a local (single country) audience, if so, avoid CDN usage.
procedure.2: Check using analytics the average distribution of your product or service's users.
procedure.3: Check a hosting or CDN provider's locations to match as closely to your customers.

examples.1: [Our World In Data](https://ourworldindata.org/internet), the [World Bank](https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/IT.NET.USER.ZS), and [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_Internet_users) provide some awesome information on average Internet usage worldwide. While this cannot replace real-world demographics, it can be helpful for new projects.

techniques.title: Avoid hosting dynamic resources or third-party scripts on the CDN
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [4.10 Use Content Delivery Networks (CDNs) appropriately](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#use-content-delivery-networks-cdns-appropriately).

description.1: Prevent non-first-party dynamic resources from being loaded through a content delivery network. The justification behind this is due to browser mechanisms such as CORS and cache partitioning, unfavorable things can occur if you try to load dynamic resources from third-party websites (this is a security measure to prevent malicious code injection).
description.2: As this issue does not affect static resources such as HTML, CSS, or JSON, when testing against the criteria, these types of resources can be excluded. For more dynamic resources like JavaScript or server-side code, if the host URL differs from your own (this includes things like frameworks), flagging up an error and recommending self-hosting or integration with existing tooling should be done.

procedure.1: Check that your CDN only contains static website assets.
procedure.2: Check that JavaScript on CDNs is first-party hosted only.

examples.1: While D3 is a well-respected JavaScript framework for producing graphs and complex charts. [It has a recommendation](https://d3js.org/getting-started) for vanilla HTML users that states a preference for a CDN package (going against our guidelines).
examples.2: [Underscore](https://underscorejs.org/) is another JavaScript framework that offers CDN packages while also offering direct download options. In this case, the download option is provided first (and code examples reflect this) which is good.

techniques.title: Provide a review or expiration date on website content
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [4.12 Store data according to the needs of your users](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#store-data-according-to-the-needs-of-your-users).

description.1: Provide a mechanism that ensures all content within a website or application gets regularly reviewed and if necessary refreshed, updated, or if it has reached the end-of-life, deleted or archived. As such, publicly providing a date when events will occur should offer an incentive for providers to action these labels (and users can note outdated content).
description.2: Machine testability should offer a grace period for content that has passed the date when a review should take place (as circumstances can lead to dates being missed), however, failings should still be flagged as potential issues that need to be resolved. Labels within the content should be detectable by scripts that issue such dates, and if they do not exist, recommendations can be issued.

procedure.1: Check that all articles (or content where material may go out-of-date) have a review or expiration date.

examples.1: On the [National Health Service](https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/migraine/) website, at the bottom of an article about a medical condition, a clear piece of text mentioning when the content was last reviewed and is next due for review is given.

techniques.title: Provide a classification policy to content if it is deemed sustainable
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [4.12 Store data according to the needs of your users](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#store-data-according-to-the-needs-of-your-users).

description.1: Increase findability within content by offering mechanisms within the page for users to filter the results of potential content they are seeking by category, tag, or other factors. How this feature is presented to users can differ between implementations as there are several well-defined patterns, but they can reduce problematic friction in the user experience.
description.2: Machine testability for such features will involve examining the page's source code to identify repeating patterns across several pages (if correctly labeled, patterns such as tags or categories may be semantically easy to find). The sustainability of such implementations must account for the impact it has upon rendering across each page, against the benefit it has to the user experience.

procedure.1: Check that content within the website (or potentially within long articles) can be filtered by classification.
procedure.2: Check that all classification patterns used on websites are repeated across all pages and clearly labeled.

examples.1: A List Apart [provides a topics page](https://alistapart.com/topics/) which groups various pieces of content (articles) into categories. By doing this it reduces the number of pages an individual will need to click through to find what they are after.
examples.2: Maggie Appleton has a [really visually appealing way](https://maggieappleton.com/garden) of laying out all of their different topics, content types, and even how well-developed their thoughts are. With all of this, you can filter their content accordingly.

techniques.title: Ensure that backup providers are classified as sustainable
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [4.12 Store data according to the needs of your users](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#store-data-according-to-the-needs-of-your-users).

description.1: Ensure that any third-party backup service provider is examined for sustainability impacts. This will involve examining the impact they have simply in hosting your data, but also how sustainable their platform is, as well as their business. If their model meets any obligations laid out and aligns well against the WSG, it may meet success criteria.
description.2: To identify how sustainable a service is, a list of recommended sustainable backup providers would be an ideal source to utilize (assuming that one exists and it is itself reputable). If no list exists, checking providers' claims, sustainability statements, and measuring their service against criteria such as the WSG can be helpful to some extent, though utilizing established standards like the GRI and recommendations around infrastructure will also help.

procedure.1: Check if the backup provider has a sustainability statement in place.
procedure.2: Check if the backup provider meets any sustainability compliance obligations.
procedure.3: Check that backup provider against the WSG for its sustainability compliance.

examples.1: An application producing large numbers of logs that need to be rotated on a regular cycle could backup those logs to an External sustainable source and remove them from the origin host to eliminate existing emissions.

techniques.title: Provide a publicly visible sustainability and/or ethical policy statement
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [5.1 Have an ethical and sustainable product strategy](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#have-an-ethical-and-sustainable-product-strategy).

description.1: Ensure that the product or service in question has the documentation to back up any claims relating to both ethical policy decisions and sustainability both offline and digitally relating to its practices. This can include anything within the scope of PPP and provide coverage of compliance with relevant legislation, standards, and best practices.
description.2: Using heuristics, machine testing can identify key passages within the text (potentially by the headlines) to check for various sections that should be present within a sustainability statement or code of ethics policy document. In addition, it is critical that the document exists and be easily found so verify its location and check that where it is referenced in the document is appropriate.

procedure.1: Check that a publicly visible sustainability statement exists.
procedure.2: Check that a Code of Ethics statement can be located.
procedure.3: Check that the sustainability statement contains details on PPP reports.
procedure.4: Check that the sustainability statement has concrete dates planned.
procedure.5: Check that the sustainability statement details legal compliance.
procedure.6: Check that the content is written in plain English for readability.

examples.1: The US Secretaries and Exchange Commission [has a useful example](https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1094007/000119312504044901/dex14.htm) regarding a code of ethics policy that leans towards ethical values. While it is focused on one industry it could easily be adapted to other sectors.
examples.2: Electronics organisation Nokia [has a page dedicated to sustainability](https://www.nokia.com/about-us/sustainability/) listing their commitments towards net-zero, their goals towards people and the planet, plus other important assets relating to PPP emissions.

techniques.title: Provide details of any beyond-the-scope sustainability features
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [5.1 Have an ethical and sustainable product strategy](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#have-an-ethical-and-sustainable-product-strategy).

description.1: Provide a mechanism within a sustainability statement to identify actions that a product or service may have undertaken that go beyond the WSG to become sustainable. These may include work from other specifications, supplementary materials to the WSG, or third-party tooling that has been created by the organization to improve sustainability.
description.2: Machine testability for such features would include identifying references to the documentation within a sustainability statement, also if tooling itself is aware of anything that is beyond the scope of the WSG and feels it warrants inclusion for improving sustainability for people and the planet, this could also be identified within the tooling and calculated into the overall scoring metrics.

procedure.1: Check for any third-party sustainability features beyond the WSG scope.
procedure.2: Check that any such features are met in both guidelines and success criteria.
procedure.3: Check that no conflicts are caused with existing WSG compliance.
procedure.4: If conflicts do exist, prioritize the WSG unless a higher classification of document exists (law, etc).

examples.1: Third-party testing tools such as [EcoGrader](https://ecograder.com/) or [Website Carbon](https://www.websitecarbon.com/) will have their own implementations of the WSG and therefore may choose to not only score differently but potentially extend the criteria being tested.
examples.2: Other specifications such as those from the [W3C](https://www.w3.org/) or RFCs from the [IETF](https://www.ietf.org/) may choose to reference sustainability best practices within the scope of their own work, based on evidence and beyond the WSG offerings.

techniques.title: Check that an employee is assigned as the sustainability representative
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [5.2 Assign a sustainability advocate](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#assign-a-sustainability-advocate).

description.1: Verify that the website or application service provider has an individual who is responsible for ensuring the sustainability of the product or service. While they may have responsibilities other than this at the business or have to answer to those with more power or influence than them, it is still an important role that needs at least one officer.
description.2: For machine testability, check the sustainability statement for contact details to verify that the individual responsible for managing such statements, coverage, and reporting, is the lead on sustainability. If no details are available, there may be hints in staff pages for agencies or companies that can be scanned against, otherwise, flag as a potential failure point. In the case of individuals, this can be ignored as they will be responsible for all aspects of a project.

procedure.1: Check for a named employee and their contact details on the sustainability statement.

examples.1: Having a digital sustainability lead, advocate, or sustainability expert who is in charge of meeting compliance targets (in the same way that you would have accessibility experts in the team) can showcase your skill set.

techniques.title: Produce awareness raising resources on sustainability
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [5.3 Inform, raise awareness, and train for sustainability](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#inform-raise-awareness-and-train-for-sustainability).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for users of a product or service to gain greater awareness not only of digital sustainability but of the website or application's journey to become more sustainable. This can involve content creation, use of social media, or other documentation that will engage their particular audience and showcase improvements over time.
description.2: Machine testing for awareness and informing can be identified by using search terms (for example "sustainability", "PPP", or "carbon"), and identifying the postings and density of those occurrences. The more content that relates to relevant subject matter (and how current it is), the more likely campaigns to increase awareness are taking place internally and externally in that community.

procedure.1: Check that the product or service's social media accounts for sustainability hashtag postings.
procedure.2: Check a product or services blog for sustainability-related postings.
procedure.3: Check a product or services footer for a sustainability hub or resources area for users.

examples.1: The BBC provides a huge wealth of information about sustainability from articles, videos, news stories, and more from its [BBC Earth websites](https://www.bbcearth.com/sustainability). This catalog of well-produced material is environmentally focused.

techniques.title: Calculate the environmental impact of your competitors
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [5.5 Calculate the environmental impact](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#calculate-the-environmental-impact).

description.1: Provide a sustainability benchmark of competitors to ensure that you maintain a regular schedule of improvements to your own work. This is something that is observed in many other aspects of business but is a great principle for having the edge over others who may want to lead the change on being environmentally friendly.
description.2: It is important to consider any third-party service in isolation when analyzing services that are independent of your own. This means that you should run that product or service against the WSG without consideration of your own results and only compare them once testing is complete. For machine testing, any competitors could be provided by the user after the website or application has been analyzed, scanned, and compared - and those sites could be then tested.

procedure.1: Check your own product or service against the WSG for a baseline score.
procedure.2: Check competitor websites against the WSG to identify where they sit sustainably.
procedure.3: Check again regularly over time to monitor potential changes that may occur.

examples.1: A manufacturer of bicycles analyzes how sustainable their website is compared to their competitors (knowing that they cannot optimize their manufacturing site any further), so they use the WSG as a benchmark.
examples.2: Two businesses are about to merge but they do not know which website they should use to preserve their ethical reputation, so they run an analysis of both to identify things to take from each creation.

techniques.title: Have a clearly defined set of sustainability goals
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [5.6 Define clear organizational sustainability goals and metrics](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#define-clear-organizational-sustainability-goals-and-metrics).

description.1: Provide a driving force for sustainable change laid out in the sustainability statement. This can contain as little or as much information as you wish but it should aim to contain realistic timescales and targets aligned with roadmapped features for users to be able to realistically identify if goals are being met over the lifespan of the project.
description.2: Machine testing such criteria should at least start with the existence of the sustainability statement, and the existence of a section on sustainability goals. If these exist then heuristic testing can identify key passages within the text relating to timeframes and potential mapped features (if these are listed), or if not, then at least bullet-pointing the number of goals being provided.

procedure.1: Check for the existence of a publicly visible sustainability statement.
procedure.2: Check that a journey or path is provided to introduce the subject.
procedure.3: Check that current carbon emissions data is provided for context.
procedure.4: Check that goals over a 1, 2, 5, 10, and beyond year plan are defined.
procedure.5: Check that the content is written in plain English for readability.

examples.1: Electronics group Nokia has a [dedicated page to sustainability](https://www.nokia.com/about-us/sustainability/) showcasing its commitments towards PPP targets and providing specific year-based deadlines to achieve them along with report links and their related blog.
examples.2: United States Mega-brand Walmart has an [extremely well crafted](https://corporate.walmart.com/purpose/sustainability.html/) sustainability hub and sub-section of their corporate website that provides interactive information on their challenge to become sustainable.

techniques.title: Verify and showcase any third-party sustainability certifications
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [5.7 Validate efforts using established third-party certifications](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#validate-efforts-using-established-third-party-certifications).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for product or service owners who have achieved certifications either as an individual or as a business in a related sustainability field (with a recognized achievement or certification) to have that accounted for in the calculation of their sustainability journey. Any such certifications should be included within a statement.
description.2: For machine testability, this would require having a compiled list of recognized certifications and achievements (that are recognized as sustainable) which could then be identified by embedded links such as images for that scheme. Testing would also need to verify member's achievements. This can be used in weighted scoring to give additional marks for going beyond the WSG criteria.

procedure.1: Check that any certifications are marked up so they can be machine-read.
procedure.2: Check that any certifications allow for validation to prove the authenticity of ownership.
procedure.3: Check that all verified certifications are weighted into the sustainability scoring process.

examples.1: Organizations that have chosen to commit to [become a B-Corporation](https://www.bcorporation.net/en-us/) will have taken steps to become more sustainable and will be required to continue to make sustainable changes to retain their status.

techniques.title: Check for any included disclosure reporting policies
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [5.8 Support mandatory disclosures and reporting](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#support-mandatory-disclosures-and-reporting).

description.1: Provide a simple mechanism to identify what reporting scheme a business may operate under (such as GRI), or if they have any available guidance regarding disclosing and reporting sustainability outside of their sustainability statement. This may come under some publicly available policy documents, or it may require internal access to locate the data.
description.2: The important step in this process is to scan through the pages of the site to identify every policy page and flag any that relate to disclosures or reporting (that mention sustainability). These will be key references that if they do not have good information architecture could be hard for the user to find. If such policies exist, ensure they are referenced within the sustainability statement.

procedure.1: Check that the business operates under a disclosure reporting policy.

examples.1: The [Global Reporting Initiative](https://www.globalreporting.org/how-to-use-the-gri-standards/gri-standards-english-language/) is a recognized standard that individuals may choose to use because of the lack of cost attached to access. It is also widely respected and can be used for conformance with legislation.
examples.2: The [International Standards Organization](https://www.iso.org/sdg) has provided several standards that can help with disclosure reporting and alignment with conformance to the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals.

techniques.title: Include public facing carbon reports on an annual basis
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [5.8 Support mandatory disclosures and reporting](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#support-mandatory-disclosures-and-reporting).

description.1: Ensure that policy decisions match up to regulatory and compliance targets for businesses and individuals aiming to become sustainable. By ensuring that you not only report your existing carbon emissions but also how you plan to reduce any remaining emissions (and be transparent with the public on this matter), you encourage trust in your brand.
description.2: For machine testability, these reports should be linked to from within the sustainability statement on your public-facing website, and if possible in an open format such as HTML (otherwise, an accessible PDF format should be used). Remember that such documents should be regularly maintained if new information that is important to your sustainability journey should come to light.

procedure.1: Check that a public-facing carbon report is published annually.
procedure.2: Check if an open format is provided, or as a fallback - PDF format.
procedure.3: Check that carbon reports are linked to from within a sustainability statement.
procedure.4: Check that the content is written in plain English for readability.

examples.1: Lego offers a [vibrant sustainability section](https://www.lego.com/en-us/sustainability) of their website focusing on not just on their environmental responsibilities but also their social considerations as well. Their reports provide highlights that align to the UN SDGs.

techniques.title: Check for any compliance related disclosure documentation
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [5.8 Support mandatory disclosures and reporting](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#support-mandatory-disclosures-and-reporting).

description.1: Encourage transparency and visibility around the shift to sustainability for products and services. By actively seeking reports that have to be submitted for compliance reasons (and verifying the data if using an open standard), we can more easily monitor how well a business or individual is meeting their obligations and reaching any targets.
description.2: Because certain content within disclosure documentation may be confidential, internal access for tooling may be required if the organization in question is unwilling to provide a publicly visible anonymized version that will still offer the same useful public data (for those interested). If the data is available, this can be used within monitoring tools to track compliance checkpoints over time.

procedure.1: Check if a CSRD report has been provided, if so, evaluate the data sustainability.

examples.1: A product that creates CSRD reports using a wizard-style interface submits that information as part of a package of data to a service that tests for sustainability and this gets added to the evidence gathering.

techniques.title: Provide a product or service maintenance agreement
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [5.10 Follow a product management and maintenance strategy](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#follow-a-product-management-and-maintenance-strategy).

description.1: Provide a location where users and customers of your website or application can easily identify to what extent you will maintain and continue to provide updates for the product or service you offer. This agreement should include details not just for the product you offer (paid or otherwise), but for the website hosting the materials, and its assets.
description.2: For machine testability, first examine that the agreement exists and that it can be easily understood (many policy documents can be written in legalese so having a plain English version should be a priority), testing tools can also identify key passages that could be highlighted as requirements for their particular needs (such as timeframes for coverage or exclusionary features).

procedure.1: Check that a product or service maintenance agreement exists.
procedure.2: Check that the content provides coverage for the product or service.
procedure.3: Check that the content is written in plain English for readability.

examples.1: PandaDoc has a [simple software maintenance agreement template](https://www.pandadoc.com/software-maintenance-agreement-template/) that could be used in cases where money is potentially being exchanged. It can be customized which could also be useful for importing into projects.
examples.2: HighGear has a working SaaS [Maintenance and Support Agreement](https://www.highgear.com/saas-maintenance-and-support-agreement/) that provides details regarding the ongoing support individuals will receive for the service and what should and should not be expected from the product.

techniques.title: Identify the iteration record of the website or application
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [5.11 Implement continuous improvement procedures](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#implement-continuous-improvement-procedures).

description.1: Verify that the product or service has a proven track record of iterating over its lifetime. Naturally, the quality of the iteration (whether those changes have been improvements) will be more difficult to quantify, however, the fact that a product or service is active and being maintained is usually a good indicator of sustainable development.
description.2: Machine testing for the iteration record is easier with open source projects as a timestamped record is usually available through the repository provider, of which you can analyze the code for impactful issues. If such access is not possible, archival or caching tools for websites can help provide a useful record of iteration over time and may (using a DIFF tool) showcase iterative alterations.

procedure.1: Check if a website or application has a history of being updated.
procedure.2: Check that the frequency is less than 12 months since the last update.
procedure.3: Check (if access to a repository is provided) that more minor than major updates occur.
procedure.4: Check (if access to a repository is provided) that structure-over-style updates occur.

examples.1: [The Wayback Machine](https://web.archive.org/) from the Internet Archive allows you to locate the historical archives of many pages and websites that have long since disappeared from the web (though they may not all function accurately).

techniques.title: Clearly label changes using a release notes feature
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [5.11 Implement continuous improvement procedures](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#implement-continuous-improvement-procedures).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for users or users of a website or application to firstly identify when changes have taken place on a product or service and secondly be able to learn about the new features in more detail (if provided) so that they can quickly adjust themselves to changes that have been made for sustainability or other reasons (reducing confusion).
description.2: Each product or service should have an associated set of release notes that should be regularly maintained, as such, version numbers within those notes should match the version number of the available versions of the product or service. In addition, release notes should be detailed and sectioned based on criteria such as additions, removals, changes, and fixes - not just a single bullet that offers little context. Links and images with more detail can also be helpful.

procedure.1: Check that a changelog has been provided for each product or service.
procedure.2: Check that modifications are categorized by the type of change.
procedure.3: Check that significant changes such as new features are well documented externally.
procedure.4: Check that the content is written in plain English for readability.

examples.1: Providing a change.log document using the [changelog](https://keepachangelog.com/en/1.1.0/) semantics, and ensuring that it remains [human readable](https://common-changelog.org/) can help products and services parse versioning data successfully, using it to highlight product changes.
examples.2: GitHub provides release notes with versioning alongside for open source projects. Our own [Web Sustainability Guidelines](https://github.com/w3c/sustainableweb-wsg/releases) has a version history (releases) page that offers details on additions, updates, and fixes.

techniques.title: Align product or service compliance with the SDGs
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [5.13 Establish if a digital product or service is necessary](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#establish-if-a-digital-product-or-service-is-necessary).

description.1: Provide additional compliance criteria for testing tools to ensure that sustainability goals are being met. As such testing tools can analyze websites to vet each product or service against the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals to decide if enough evidence exists within WSG compliance (and other criteria) to pass or fail applicable categories.
description.2: Because the SDGs may have scope beyond the WSG, both individuals and testing tools must develop criteria that meet the strict requirements of each category to be considered a compliance pass or fail. As such, it may require additional input from the tester, internal access, or additional measurements and evidence gathering undertaken (with scores adjusted).

procedure.1: Check if the product aligns with the SDGs and if not, identify ways to address shortcomings.

examples.1: The [Royal Academy for Engineering](https://raeng.org.uk/sdgs) showcases each of the SDGs as a map and upon clicking each one you get taken to a dedicated page with information provided about how engineers are working to solve the issue.

techniques.title: Provide a publicly visible and transparent supplier policy
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [5.14 Provide a supplier standards of practice document](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#provide-a-supplier-standards-of-practice-document).

description.1: Both increase transparency within an organization and to ensure that users and customers can see how suppliers and potential suppliers in the supply chain are vetted to ensure that they meet sustainable guidance set up by the organization. This can relate to the things purchased, or even the business and the way it operates.
description.2: Machine testing a supplier policy first requires detection that the policy exists in a public area of a website or application. Once detected, the list of suppliers can be gathered and unless the provider has already been validated by a verified third-party, conditions for testing can be identified and listed by the tool. If not, consider testing that supplier as a first-party against the WSG (if a digital service is given), otherwise, test against other compliance targets.

procedure.1: Check that a publicly visible supplier policy exists on the website.
procedure.2: Check that information covering all three aspects of PPP are covered.
procedure.3: Check that third-party supplier against the WSG for sustainability.
procedure.4: If the supplier has a poor impact record post-testing, reconsider usage.
procedure.5: Check that the content is written in plain English for readability.

examples.1: Mobile Phone company Telefonica has a Supply Chain [Sustainability Policy document](https://www.telefonica.com/en/wp-content/uploads/sites/5/2021/07/Policy-Sustainability-Supply-Chain.pdf) (PDF) that outlines its ethical standpoint regarding people and the planet as defined by the SDGs and how it does trade.

techniques.title: Publicly list the sustainability impact of any partnerships
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [5.14 Provide a supplier standards of practice document](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#provide-a-supplier-standards-of-practice-document).

description.1: Provide a mechanism where members of the public who view a supplier policy document within your website can easily view the sustainability impact that working with each supplier will have on your product or service. This can be measured in many ways, but a detailed report of any benefits, issues, and solutions over time is helpful.
description.2: Identifying that a list of partners exists is key, if a list of partners exists then attempting to verify the impact of those services should first be found on the website itself. If the information is not found, flagging the issue and attempting to test the partners individually against the WSG would be an ideal next step (in a similar fashion to competitor analysis) to identify problematic relationships.

procedure.1: Check that all partnerships of the product or service are listed online.
procedure.2: Check those partners against public lists of known greenwashers.
procedure.3: Check those partners against the WSG for sustainability conformance.
procedure.4: If the supplier has a poor impact record post-testing, reconsider usage.

examples.1: A business with an impeccable sustainability record is offered the opportunity to partner with an oil and gas company for financial gain. Because of the conflict this would create, they chose to turn it down.

techniques.title: Ensure that the business is a living wage employer
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [5.15 Share economic benefits](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#share-economic-benefits).

description.1: Provide a mechanism to ensure that all employees are paid a living wage. The mechanism for including this within a product or service for a business could be as simple as a living wage badge in their sustainability statement (or website footer), or for additional points, publishing transparent pay grades across the business on the website.
description.2: Heuristic testing by examining the source code of a document on the employee benefits (pay grades) on a website would be able to identify whether that business is a living wage employer, as would comparing any existing job openings with pay grades against living wage rates. If these are not available, a living wage badge may be an indicator but evidence will need to back the claim.

procedure.1: Check for a listing in the living wage directory or a verifiable declaration.
procedure.2: Check the jobs page of a product or service to identify listed wages.
procedure.3: Check those wages against the Living Wage current rates.
procedure.4: If the wage is not shown or does not match, flag a potential issue.

examples.1: The [Living Wage website](https://www.livingwage.org.uk/accredited-living-wage-employers) provides a search service to allow individuals to find businesses and employers who provide a Living Wage. This can be broken down by sector, region, industry, and even service type.

techniques.title: Ensure that the business provides benefits for employees
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [5.15 Share economic benefits](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#share-economic-benefits).

description.1: Verify that a business offers a variety of benefits to its employees to make their working life better. This has coverage in the people aspect of PPP and therefore is important for sustainability. These benefits do not have to be limited to in-work additions but could be anything that employees utilize and find beneficial in or out of the workplace.
description.2: Machine testing for such benefits can be difficult as there is not a universal list of what can be offered, however, there is a commonality between the types of things that workplaces often provide. As such, analyzing words in job openings or culture/workplace pages on websites can identify these benefits and weigh the value (potentially) based on their impact (sustainably or otherwise).

procedure.1: Check the work, culture, career, and jobs pages for potential benefits.
procedure.2: Calculate values for such benefits based on their potential usefulness.
procedure.3: Check if the added value of such benefits is likely to benefit workers.

examples.1: [Wholegrain Digital is a great example](https://www.wholegraindigital.com/jobs/) of a careers/life at work page done well that showcases the benefits that will be gained from working within the organization and also the benefits that will be gained outside of payment.
examples.2: Rocketmakers provide information [about their values](https://www.rocketmakers.com/careers) (the benefits they hope to get from workers) as well as the benefits they offer (outside of the wage). It is a visually striking layout as well which helps sell the appeal.

techniques.title: Provide a publicly visible accessibility statement
