techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [5.17 Use Justice, Equity, Diversity, Inclusion (JEDI) practices](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#use-justice-equity-diversity-inclusion-jedi-practices).

description.1: Ensure that users are made aware of (or able to find out) the lengths that a product or service has gone to, ensuring that individuals with accessibility needs have been included in the design and development of the product or service. It should also aim to describe any limitations of the product or service and how to submit a support request.
description.2: The European Environment Agency provides a simple but effective accessibility statement that underlines compatibility issues and levels of support with existing web standards that users need to be aware of.

procedure.1: Check for a publicly visible accessibility statement on the website.
procedure.2: Check for a section detailing accessibility compatibility.
procedure.3: Check for a section on accessibility features built-in.
procedure.4: Check for a section listing support and known issues.
procedure.5: Check that the content is written in plain English for readability.

examples.1: United Kingdom charity Scope [provides a comprehensive](https://www.scope.org.uk/accessibility/) website accessibility statement that showcases their commitment to accessibility along with adaptations made and issues they are aware of to resolve.
examples.2: The European Environment Agency provides a simple but effective [accessibility statement](https://www.eea.europa.eu/en/accessibility) that underlines compatibility issues and levels of support with existing web standards that users need to be aware of.

techniques.title: Provide links to the privacy policy and relevant legislation
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [5.18 Promote responsible data practices](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#promote-responsible-data-practices).

description.1: Ensure that users can access a publicly visible privacy policy and that the content is human-readable, containing references to legislation that the website or application meets for compliance purposes (and how this is achieved). As privacy falls under the people aspect of PPP conformance, this has sustainability implications and should be followed.
description.2: If the product or service is accessible or operates within multiple jurisdictions, testers should take this into account when identifying relevant legislation that should be included within the policy document. The document should be visible within the footer of a website or a section alongside other relevant policy files and documents such as the accessibility and sustainability statement.

procedure.1: Check that a publicly visible privacy policy on the website.
procedure.2: Check that the privacy policy includes sections on required legislation.
procedure.3: If in Germany, check that an Impressum document is available.
procedure.4: Check that the content is written in plain English for readability.

examples.1: DK Oldies has a [simple privacy policy](https://www.dkoldies.com/privacy/) that breaks down everything into categories and bullet points for each of the term conditions to make the information easier to comprehend for those who wish to read everything.
examples.2: Sony Pictures has a [more comprehensive](https://www.sonypictures.co.uk/privacy-policy) privacy policy that uses bullet points to break down information into key facts but offers more technical language and detail that could be problematic for some people.

techniques.title: Provide a website archive containing outdated or old versions
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [5.19 Implement appropriate data management procedures](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#implement-appropriate-data-management-procedures).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for retrieving old information that may have expired in terms of currency, but may still have a practical use as a reference for individuals wishing to identify information that had prior use or relevance for a product or service. This technique is most useful when the information is content-focused or showcasing iterative change.
description.2: For machine testability, several criteria should be taken into account. Firstly the outdated material should be isolated either on a subdomain or a subfolder to avoid clashing with existing content. This material should also be reduced to a minimalist form (content only) to reduce sustainability impacts. Furthermore, all links should be checked to ensure that they resolve to a working reference.

procedure.1: Check if content exists beyond 5-10 years on the website or application.
procedure.2: Check if the mentioned content is being accessed rarely rather than regularly.
procedure.3: Check (if both of the above are true) that a website archive holds this material.
procedure.4: Check that the mentioned archive is slimmed down to further reduce sustainability impacts.

examples.1: A magazine decides to maintain issues spanning 12 months (one year) on its website to maintain currency, however, for content older than this, it will be archived on a slimmer website with click-to-reveal media available.

techniques.title: Enable users to manage their accounts and data
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [5.19 Implement appropriate data management procedures](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#implement-appropriate-data-management-procedures).

description.1: Offer a mechanism for users of a product or service to allow the management of any information (data) or accounts (subscription or otherwise) they may hold. Best practices with such systems will include allowing the deletion of accounts and/or data without human intervention and providing single steps (with confirmation) to achieve this.
description.2: Machine testing such features will undoubtedly require internal access for a product or service, however, if the ability to create an account can be automated or undertaken, then the visibility of the source code within the account management system can be verified by tooling. As such, where internal access is required, gain permission, then check for the ability to delete accounts (and verify that this action works), if it does, pass the check.

procedure.1: Check that users can delete their accounts and data without human intervention.

examples.1: A Software as a Service provider has within the account manager, a profile section allowing customers to click a big red button to "delete account and data". Upon hitting confirm, this erases their details from the servers.

techniques.title: Provide a publicly facing policy around emerging technologies
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [5.20 Establish responsible practices around AI and emerging or disruptive technologies](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#establish-responsible-practices-around-ai-and-emerging-or-disruptive-technologies).

description.1: Offer a document that describes in detail any mechanisms that a product or service has in place regarding emerging technologies such as artificial intelligence, cryptocurrencies, or other impactful (sustainably speaking) aspects of the web. If none of these features are likely to be used by you or your suppliers, state so, otherwise, provide details.
description.2: For machine testability, it is important to ensure that such a document exists as emerging technologies are having an increasingly impactful effect on the sustainability of the Internet. As such, if no statement exists, flag this concern. If one does exist, check what technologies are being utilized, to what extent, and weigh these in subsequent calculations (raising issues as appropriate).

procedure.1: Check that a publicly facing policy exists around emerging technology usage.
procedure.2: Check (if such technology is used) to what extent and how much of an impact this is causing.
procedure.3: Check that the content is written in plain English for readability.

examples.1: A service that provides customers with the ability to remotely monitor and control appliances in their homes utilizes the Information of Things. In their policy document, they outline how this benefits and risks sustainability.
examples.2: A SaaS product uses Artificial Intelligence to screen customers for health issues before seeing a medical professional. The policy covers impact issues such as risks of discrimination, emissions, and other PPP factors.

techniques.title: Verify all partnerships and sponsors against the WSG
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [5.21 Include responsible financial policies](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#include-responsible-financial-policies).

description.1: Ensure that if an individual or organization is being endorsed or financed by an external group or organization, the influence that the group may provide is sustainably minded (and will not divert the product or service away from such activities). Ensuring all endorsements are sustainable can also help service providers avoid claims of greenwashing.
description.2: Machine testing such factors will require firstly all partnerships and sponsors to be correctly labeled as such, if they are labeled within the product or service then the tester can test each of these services against the WSG as a first-party (an isolated service) and verify how sustainable they are in comparison. If they score poorly, a warning of conflict of interest issues can be provided.

procedure.1: Check that all partnerships and sponsors are publicly listed on the website.
procedure.2: Check that all listings are correctly marked up so they can be machine-read.
procedure.3: Check that all partnerships and sponsors are vetted against public lists of known greenwashers.
procedure.4: Check that all partnerships and sponsors are tested against the WSG for sustainability.
procedure.5: If the supplier has a poor impact record post-testing, reconsider usage.

examples.1: In 2024, The [Science Museum](https://www.sciencemuseum.org.uk/about-us/support-us/corporate-partnerships) (London) decided to run a gallery promoting sustainability, however, due to their sponsorship by Oil and Gas giants this caused [repetitional damage and greenwashing accusations](https://www.museumsassociation.org/museums-journal/news/2024/03/science-museums-green-energy-gallery-opens-amid-protests-over-sponsorship/#).

techniques.title: Verify and showcase any third-party sustainability projects
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [5.22 Include organizational philanthropy policies](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#include-organizational-philanthropy-policies).

description.1: Identify any third-party projects connected with the product or service that can be verified as sustainability causes or schemes of value that may benefit either the business on its sustainability journey or directly lead to improvements for people or the planet. Schemes can include reinvesting in the ecosystem, or community, or reducing emissions.
description.2: For machine testability, this would require having a compiled list of recognized schemes (that are recognized as sustainable) which could then be identified by embedded links such as images for that scheme. Testing could also check schemes that support verifying members as required. This could be used in weighted scoring to give additional marks for going beyond our guidelines.

procedure.1: Check that all third-party projects are publicly listed on the website.
procedure.2: Check that all listings are correctly marked up so they can be machine-read.
procedure.3: Check that third-party projects are weighted into the sustainability scoring process.

examples.1: [1% for the Planet](https://www.onepercentfortheplanet.org/) is a certified scheme that asks businesses involved to commit one percent of their earnings towards planetary projects. As a well-established scheme, it has generated a lot of income for environmental causes.
examples.2: [Krystal hosting](https://krystal.io/green) showcases a great number of projects that they are actively involved with. This ranges from financial investment to carbon offsetting and climate/sustainability commitment memberships.

techniques.title: Provide a sustainability and environmental budget
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [5.25 Define performance and environmental budgets](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#define-performance-and-environmental-budgets).

description.1: Provide a clearly defined set of targets to achieve when working to either make an existing project more sustainable or create a newly sustainable website or application. Just as with performance budgets, you can define the factors that are most achievable and iterate with more factors (and improvements) to be included over a project's lifecycle.
description.2: For machine testability, the budget (often provided in a format like JSON) will either be required to be submitted to the testing agent or be declared in some other manner to ensure that any results can be compared against the budget for alignment. If the budget is met, a pass can be given, if not, a warning can be issued with recommendations where potential improvements can be made.

procedure.1: Check that any budget information provided by the user is in a valid format.
procedure.2: Check to see if the user has submitted a JSON budget with predefined labels and values.
procedure.3: Check that the WSG conformance (against success criteria) matches or is lower than the budget.

examples.1: A video streaming service wishes to build a sustainability budget based on the WSG so defines KPIs around each success criterion with a defined numerical value that must be achieved during machine testing stages.

techniques.title: Provide a performance budget for your product or service
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [5.25 Define performance and environmental budgets](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#define-performance-and-environmental-budgets).

description.1: Provide a clearly defined set of targets to achieve when working to either make an existing project more performant or create a new website or application fast and optimized. As with a sustainability budget, you should define the factors that are most relevant to your project and consider targets that will make a sustainable difference to your users.
description.2: For machine testability, the budget (often provided in a format like JSON) will either be required to be submitted to the testing agent or be declared in some other manner to ensure that any results can be compared against the budget for alignment. If the budget is met, a pass can be given, if not, a warning can be issued with recommendations where potential improvements can be made.

procedure.1: Check that any budget information provided by the user is in a valid format.
procedure.2: Check to see if the user has submitted a JSON budget with predefined labels and values.
procedure.3: Check that the performance criteria match or is lower than the budget.

examples.1: [Performance Budget](https://www.performancebudget.io/) allows you to set targets for the web performance of your product or service based on either a series of assets or Core Web Vitals. You can import these defined targets into Google Lighthouse.

techniques.title: Benchmark the improvement in revised budget achievements
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [5.25 Define performance and environmental budgets](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#define-performance-and-environmental-budgets).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for service providers to monitor the sustainability or performance improvements that occur over time when revising their budgets to meet stricter targets after they meet existing ones. This will require constant monitoring of existing products or services to ensure that goals are being met and that budgets are improving for the better.
description.2: As with all budget-related guidance, the budget (often provided in a format like JSON) will either be required to be submitted to the testing agent or be declared in some other manner so that previous and current targets can be reviewed over time. In addition, monitoring tools should note when targets are reached and indicate the potential to achieve new goals to better their work.

procedure.1: Check that any budget information provided by the user is in a valid format.
procedure.2: Check to see if the user has submitted a JSON budget with predefined labels and values.
procedure.3: Check the submitted information against previously submitted budgets.
procedure.4: Check that the new budgets are equal or tighter (smaller) targets than previously.
procedure.5: Check the website or application's budget analysis data against previous tests.
procedure.6: Check that the website or application meets budget requirements regularly.

examples.1: An application that decides to redesign its product after user-testing indicates that it would significantly improve the sustainability of the service. Post redesign, the budget is met so new targets are chosen.

techniques.title: Produce an open source policy and verify licensing
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [5.26 Use open source where possible](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#use-open-source-where-possible).

description.1: Consider the place that open source has in a product or service. If open source (for example) is used within code libraries such as frameworks, these should be identified and the license type should be verified to ensure compliance occurs (for instance, attribution). If the business in question is supportive of open source, this should also be noted publicly.
description.2: Identifying an open source license should be straightforward, especially if the product or service utilizes a public repository system like GitHub. In addition, source code can be scanned for required attribution references and if an open source policy exists within either the license agreement on the website or in its own document, this can be highlighted as working towards compliance.

procedure.1: Check that a publicly facing open source policy exists on the website.
procedure.2: Check that the policy contains content about creation and contribution.
procedure.3: Check that the content is written in plain English for readability.

examples.1: The Todo Group has a collection on GitHub of [Open Source Policies](https://github.com/todogroup/policies?tab=readme-ov-file) which can provide useful inspiration in describing how various companies got into open source and what their policy for such community work is.

techniques.title: Identify contributions made to open source projects
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [5.26 Use open source where possible](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#use-open-source-where-possible).

description.1: Provide a mechanism to identify any open source work an individual or business may have made which gives back to the community. Open source and working on collaborative projects is a sustainable way of helping to evolve knowledge around digital issues and as such should be referenced in meeting sustainability objectives (especially high profile work).
description.2: Machine testing open source will require first identifying a public repository associated with the website or project (this is usually indicated using a social link button). Once this has been established, identifying the projects to which the group or members are the source or a contributor to (including activity levels) can be weighed to determine compliance with the success criteria.

procedure.1: Check a product or service's website for a link to a public repository.
procedure.2: Check for projects where group members are the source or contributor.
procedure.3: Check activity levels for open source work are consistent and not irregular.

examples.1: Many web designers and developers have a link to their GitHub repository on their personal portfolio. This allows prospective clients and casual viewers to see all of the cool open source work they have contributed to.

techniques.title: Maintain transparent communication when problems occur
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [5.27 Create a business continuity and disaster recovery plan](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#create-a-business-continuity-and-disaster-recovery-plan).

description.1: During downtime or when issues occur, it is critical that users or users can understand what is happening to the product or service, why it is happening (if known), and when the service is likely to be restored. This will help ensure continuity of service and if a backup or alternative can be offered, provide a way of reducing wasted resources attempting to keep reloading the non-functioning feature.
description.2: Machine testing for how users are kept informed and provided with alternative methods of interacting with the product or service could be through the use of a third-party provider that takes the slack when the first-party becomes unavailable, the use of archived material (identified by the content) could also be an indicator or the content provided on some kind of automatically updating channel that lists ongoing issues.

procedure.1: Check for backups that are stored in a read-only, recoverable state (internal access).
procedure.2: Check for a public-facing policy relating to disaster recovery and continuity.
procedure.3: Check for a system status page and that everything is running correctly.

examples.1: [System status pages](https://www.githubstatus.com/) can be a useful customer metric for keeping up-to-date with ongoing issues and reducing the burden of customer support if something widespread happens to a product or service. It does produce reliance on a third-party but its sustainability benefits relate to the business governance and the data from the product can feed into improving ideation which can include improving all-round sustainability.
